   The permit fee for a massage business shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00)
per year or any part thereof. The permit fee for masseurs shall be twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) per year or any part thereof. (Ord. 90865. Passed 12-17-75.)
   751.13 REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF PERMIT.
   Any massage business or masseur's permit issued under this chapter shall be
subject to suspension or revocation by the Police Chief for violation of any
provision of this chapter, or for any grounds that would warrant the denial of
issuance of such permit in the first place. The Chief, upon such revocation or
suspension, shall state his reasons in writing, specifying the particular
grounds for such revocation or suspension. (Ord. 90865. Passed 12-17-75.)
   751.14 KEEPING OF RECORDS.
   Every person who operates a massage business or practices or provides a
massage shall at all times keep an appointment book in which the name of each
and every patron shall be entered, together with the time, date and place of
service, and the service provided. Such appointment book shall be available at
all times for inspection by the Police Chief or his authorized representative.
(Ord. 90865. Passed 12-17-75.)
   751.15 TRANSFERS PROHIBITED.
   No massage business and masseur permits are transferable, separate or
divisible, and such authority as a permit confers shall be conferred only on
the permittee named therein.
(Ord. 90865. Passed 12-17-75.)
   751.99 PENALTY.
   (a) Whoever violates Section
751.08 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree.
   (b) Whoever violates any other provision of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree; a separate offense shall be deemed committed
on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 90865.
Passed 12-17-75.)
CHAPTER 753
Mechanical Amusement Devices
753.01   Definition.
753.02   License required; display.
753.03   License fee.
753.04   Hours for minors restricted.
753.05   Internet game cafes and sweepstakes businesses.
753.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Making or using slugs - see GEN. OFF.
545.11
Tampering with coin machines - see GEN. OFF.
545.12
   753.01 DEFINITION.
   "Mechanical amusement device", as used in this chapter, shall be construed
to mean any player piano, music box, Victrola, radio or any musical contrivance
or device constructed or designed to produce or reproduce music automatically
and any mechanical device held out for amusement purpose which can be operated
or placed in condition to operate by the insertion of a coin or slug or payment
of a fee. (1967 Code §114.41)
   753.02 LICENSE REQUIRED; DISPLAY.
   No person shall operate, maintain, place or permit to be located in a place
where the same can be operated, any mechanical amusement device without first
having secured a license therefor and without displaying the license in plain
view either on the device or in the place where the same is located. (1967 Code
§114.42)
   753.03 LICENSE FEE.
   Effective January 1, 2005, the annual fee for the license required by
Section
753.02 shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) for the first mechanical amusement
device owned or operated, and ten dollars ($10.00) for each additional device
owned or operated. All such licenses shall expire on December 31 of the year of
issuance.
(Ord. 04-166. Passed 7-21-04.)
   753.04 HOURS FOR MINORS RESTRICTED.
   No person shall permit anyone under eighteen years of age to enter upon the
premises, play, engage in or operate any mechanical amusement device, unless
accompanied by a parent or legal guardian thereof between the hours of 9:00
a.m. and 11:00 p.m. eastern standard time or daylight savings time whichever is
in effect. (Ord. 92150. Passed 6-9-76.)
   753.05 INTERNET GAME CAFES AND SWEEPSTAKES BUSINESSES.
   (a)    Definitions:
      (1)   “Internet Game Café” means any business, establishment, room or
place where entertainment devices are kept for use by the public or by persons
other than the owner of the devices, where persons give anything of value to
access the use of the entertainment devices or the premises, and the person may
be given anything of value by the operator whether the giving occurs on or off
the premises or at the same or a later time.
      (2)   “Entertainment Device” means any mechanical, electronic, video or
digital device that is capable of accepting anything of value, directly or
indirectly, from or on behalf of a person, for the purpose of playing a game,
viewing a video display, hearing an audio transmission or reading entries or
outcomes from any other kind of device. "Entertainment device" does not include
any vending maching, juke box, audio book, video player or any device that
gives anything of value where the only value given, directly or indirectly, is
a video or audio transmission or the playing of a game.
      (3)   “Anything of Value” means any cash, cash equivalents, tangible
objects, credits to play, sweepstakes entry points and any tangibles, no matter
how slight. “Anything of value” includes playing a game, viewing a video
display, hearing an audio transmission, and reading entries or outcomes from
any other kind of device. A person who gives anything of value for a product or
service, whether tangible or intangible, in any way, directly or indirectly, in
association with being given access to the use of an entertainment device, is
deemed to have given value for the access to the entertainment device.
      (4)   “Sweepstakes Business” means any privately owned business operating
in the City of Youngstown where adults may purchase a product for value that
enters the adult into a lottery with a predetermined winner or in which skill
does not determine the winner, or any other Schemes of Chance. The purchase of
the product gives the adult credits to play computer based games necessary to
win the lottery. The number of credits provided by the purchase is directly
correlated to the value of the purchase. A business which provides the
opportunity to play a machine/computer based game for the purpose of
discovering lottery results is also a sweepstakes business, even if the
purchase of a product does not require participation in the computer game for
entry to win.
      (5)   “Owner” or “Operator” means the person or business entity that owns
or leases premises to operate an internet game cafe or sweepstakes business on
those premises and receives any or all profits from the business.
      (6)   “Principals in a Business Venture” include all partners, officers,
and major shareholders.
      (7)   “On-Site Manager” means the person in charge of operating and
carrying out the day to day management of an internet game cafe or sweepstakes
business at the permitted location.
   (b)    Licensing and Fees. Any owner or operator of an Internet Game Cafe or
Sweepstakes Business shall annually apply for a permit to operate within the
City. If the business or cafe contains fewer than 4 machines and/or computers,
then the operator shall apply for a permit for each public machine and/or
computer in the amount of $250 per device. Should the business or cafe contain
four or more machines and/or computers, but fewer than 100 machines and/or
computers, then the owner shall pay $4,000 annually for a permit to operate as
an Internet Game Cafe or Sweepstakes Business. If the business or cafe contains
more than 100 machines and/or computers, the owner or operator shall pay $6,000
annually for a permit to operate as an Internet Game Café or Sweepstakes
Business.
   Every Internet Game Cafe or Sweepstakes Business shall pay a semiannual tax
of $25 per machine and/or computer payable on the first Monday of January and
the first Monday of July every year. Should the business cease to operate, the
tax will be prorated for the period that the machines and/ or computers were in
use.
   (c)   Contents of Application. Each owner or operator shall include with the
application an affidavit stating whether he/she is a sole proprietor, a
partnership, corporation or other joint venture and listing the names of all
principals in the business venture.
   Each Applicant shall include with the application an affidavit certifying
that the specific games which will be operated by the applicant as part of a
sweepstakes business or internet cafe are not slot machines or other illegal
games of chance.
   Each applicant shall include with the application a certification from the
State of Ohio or an authorized testing agency which indicates that the specific
games which will be operated by the applicant as part of a Sweepstakes Business
or Internet Game Café are legal to operate in the State of Ohio and are not
slot machines or other Games of Chance should the State of Ohio offer a
procedure to obtain such certification.
   Each Applicant, and in the case of a partnership, corporation or other
business venture in which two or more parties are principals, all principals
shall be required to submit to a background check to verify that he/she is not
a person prohibited from being issued a permit under this section. If the
Applicant is not the actual on-site manager of the internet cafe for which the
permit is issued, then the manager of such cafe shall be required to submit to
a background check as well.
The cost of background checks required herein is to be paid by the Applicant.
   Each applicant shall be required to list all machines and/or computers being
operated or to be operated by the applicant, such list to include the following
information:
      (1)   The make, model and serial number of each machine and/or computer
operated or to operate as a skill based game or scheme of chance;
      (2)   The hardware and/or circuit board switch settings for each machine
and/or computer operated or to operate as a skill based game or scheme of
chance;
      (3)   The software setting of each such machine and/or computer; and
      (4)   A copy of each manual for any such machine and/ or computer
operated or to operate as a skill based game or scheme of chance.
   Each permit holder shall, within ten (10) days of any change with regard to
paragraphs (1) through (4) above, be required to notify the City in writing of
any such change and the date of such change.
   (d)   Prohibited Persons and Revocation of Permit. None of the following
persons or entities shall be eligible to hold a permit or to manage or operate
an Internet Game Cafe or Sweepstakes Business pursuant to subsection (b)
hereof:
      (1)   A person convicted of a felony pursuant to the laws of this State,
any other state, or the United States.
      (2)   A person convicted of any crime involving fraud, dishonesty, or
moral turpitude, pursuant to the laws of this State, any other State, or the
United States.
      (3)   A person who has been convicted of a gambling offense under Chapter
2915 of the Ohio Revised Code, Chapter
517 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Youngstown, or any substantially
similar law of any other state or the United States.
      (4)   A person who has been convicted of any violation of this section.
      (5)   A person who has been a defendant party to a nuisance abatement
action pursuant to Chapter 3767 of the Ohio Revised Code.
      (6)   Any corporation, partnership or other legal entity or organization
that has been convicted of any of the offenses set forth in paragraphs (1)
through (5) above.
   In the event that any person or entity that has been granted a permit
pursuant to subsection (b) hereof becomes ineligible to hold such a permit due
to a conviction for any of the offenses set forth in paragraphs (1) through (6)
above, that permit shall result in immediate revocation of the permit holder's
permit as of the date of conviction. Continued operation of an Internet Game
Cafe or Sweepstakes Business shall constitute a nuisance that is subject to
abatement pursuant to Chapter 3767 of the Ohio Revised Code, in addition to any
other remedies at the disposal of the City of Youngstown.
   (e)   Inspection. Each permit holder is subject to inspection by the Vice
Department of the Youngstown City Police Department during normal business
hours to ensure the permit holder's compliance with the provision of this
chapter, Chapter
517 of the City of Youngstown Codified Ordinances, and Chapter 2915 of the Ohio
Revised Code. Failure of the permit holder to allow the Vice Department of the
Youngstown City Police to inspect during normal business hours shall result in
immediate revocation of the permit holder's permit.
   (f)   Adults Only. No person shall permit anyone under eighteen years of age
to enter upon the premises, play, engage in or operate any machine and/or
computer, unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian thereof.
   (g)   Location Restrictions. Each Internet Game Cafe or Sweepstakes Business
shall comply with all zoning and land use ordinances, requirements, codes and
regulations of the City of Youngstown.
   (h)   State Law. The issuance of a license under this section is not
intended to indicate that the actions of the licenseholder are or will be
deemed in compliance with the laws of the State of Ohio or insulate the
licenseholder from prosecution thereunder. In the event the State of Ohio
passes legislation outlawing the possession or use of any of the devices or the
business operations permitted hereunder, the permit issued is subject to
immediate revocation.
   (i)   Prohibited Operation. 
      (1)    No person shall operate a business as an Internet Game Café or
Sweepstakes Business without a license issued pursuant to this section or in
violation of this section. This section is intended to impose strict liability.
Lack of knowledge or intent is not a defense to a violation hereof.
      (2)    No person, being the owner or lessee, or having custody, control,
or supervision of premises, shall recklessly permit such premises to be used or
occupied for an unlicensed Internet Game Cafe or Sweepstakes Business.
      (3)    No person, being the owner or lessee, or having custody, control,
or supervision, of a hotel, restaurant, tavern, store, arena, hall, or other
place of public accommodation, business, amusement, or resort shall recklessly
permit those premises to be used or occupied for an unlicensed Internet Game
Cafe or Sweepstakes Business.
      (4)    No person shall violate any other provision of this section. This
section is intended to impose strict liability. Lack of knowledge or intent is
not a defense to a violation hereof.
      (5)   The issuance of this license is not intended to reflect any
determination by the City of Youngstown that the machines or computers taxed
hereunder are or are not considered gambling devices under State Law.
      (6)   The City shall not be liable to any license holder on any theory
that the licensee relied upon the issuance of a license pursuant to this
section as certifying that their operations or games, machines or computers
comply with state gambling laws.
   (j)   Penalty.  Any violation of this section is a misdemeanor of the first
degree. Each and every day the business operates without a license issued
pursuant to this section shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 11-130. Passed 4-20-11.)
   753.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.
CHAPTER 757
Pawnbrokers
757.01   Definition.
757.02   License termination date.
757.03   License transferability.
757.04   Records to be kept; contents and methods.
757.05   Police inspection of records.
757.06   Daily report.
757.07   Holding period.
757.08   Employees; minimum age limit.
757.09   Certain dealings prohibited.
757.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
Pawnbrokers - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4727
Maximum interest and charges allowed - see Ohio R.C. 4727.06
Daily report to police department - see Ohio R.C. 4727.09
Purchase from minor or drunkard prohibited - see Ohio R.C. 4727.10
Secondhand stores - see BUS. REG. Ch.
747
   757.01 DEFINITION.
   "Pawnbroker", as used in this chapter, means a person who makes a business
of lending money on the security of personal property pledged in the keeping on
condition of selling the same back again at a stipulated price, or purchasing
precious or semi-precious metals or jewelry.
(Ord. 10-385. Passed 12-15-10.)
   757.02 LICENSE TERMINATION DATE.
   All licenses issued under this chapter shall terminate at midnight on the
night of December 31 in the year in which issued. (1967 Code §111.20)
   757.03 LICENSE TRANSFERABILITY.
   All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be void if
transferred.
(1967 Code §111.21)
   757.04 RECORDS TO BE KEPT; CONTENTS AND METHODS.
   Every person licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall keep a
correct list and description in a book for that purpose, of every article
pledged or deposited with him, or on which advances of money have been made, or
which may have been purchased by him. Each entry shall be numbered
consecutively commencing with number one and shall, at all times, when required
by the police officer or Mayor as provided by Section
757.05, produce and show any article so listed and described which may be in
his possession. He shall also register in the book the name and place of
residence of the depositor and time when the deposit was made. All entries
shall be written in ink in the English language, and no entry shall be erased,
obliterated or defaced.
(1967 Code §111.22)
   757.05 POLICE INSPECTION OF RECORDS.
   The record required to be kept by Section
757.04 shall at all times be open to the inspection of the Police Chief, or of
a police officer deputized by him, to make such inspection, or by the Mayor.
(1967 Code §111.23)
   757.06 DAILY REPORT.
   Every person licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall prepare and
deliver every day to the Chief of Police, before the hour of 12:00 midnight, a
legible and correct copy written in English, from the book required to be kept
by Section
757.04, and such copy shall be made upon blank forms prepared and furnished by
the Police Department and shall consist of a full and complete description of
all personal property, bonds, notes or other securities received on deposit or
purchased during the preceding day, together with the hour at which the article
was received, together with a description of the person by whom left in pledge,
or from whom the same were purchased and each entry of such copy shall bear the
same consecutive number as the entry in such book. (1967 Code §111.24)
   757.07 HOLDING PERIOD.
   No bond, note, security or personal property of any kind, received on
deposit, purchased or pledged by any such pawnbroker shall be sold or permitted
to be redeemed or removed from the place of business of such pawnbroker for a
period of twenty-four hours after the copy and statement provided for in
Section
757.04 has been delivered to the Chief of Police as provided in Section
757.06. (1967 Code §111.25)
   757.08 EMPLOYEES; MINIMUM AGE LIMIT.
   No pawnbroker shall employ any person under the age of sixteen to take
pledges in pawn. (1967 Code §111.28)
   757.09 CERTAIN DEALINGS PROHIBITED.
   No person licensed under this chapter shall take or receive in pawn or
pledge for money loaned, or shall take, receive or purchase within the lines of
his business as a pawnbroker, any property, bonds, notes, securities, articles,
mechanic's tool, instrument or device having upon it any initials or insignia
of ownership, or thing whatsoever, from any minor, or the ownership of which is
in or which is claimed by any minor, or which may be in the possession of or
under the control of any minor, or a person appearing to be intoxicated, a
person known to be a notorious thief, a person known to have been convicted of
larceny or burglary, or a person not being able to furnish complete
identification of ownership. (1967 Code §111.29)
   757.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the fourth degree. Each day's continued violation shall constitute a separate
offense.
CHAPTER 760
Oil and Gas Wells
760.01   Standards adopted.
760.02   Permit required.
760.03   Permit application; review.
760.04   Regulations.
760.05   Damages; financial responsibility; bond.
760.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
State law provisions - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1509
Oil and gas well drilling - see OAC Ch. 1501:9-1, 1501:9-9
   760.01 STANDARDS ADOPTED.
   The City hereby adopts the standards contained in Ohio R.C. Chapter 1509 for
the drilling, constructing, reopening, converting, plugging back, plugging,
operating, maintaining and abandoning of any oil or gas well within the City.
(Ord. 89-47. Passed 5-24-89.)
   760.02 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall, within the limits of the City, drill a
new oil or gas well, drill an existing oil or gas well any deeper, reopen an
oil or gas well, convert an oil or gas well to any use other than its original
purpose, or plug back an oil or gas well to a source of supply different from
the existing pool, without first having obtained a permit to do so from the
Chief of the Division of Oil and Gas of the Ohio Department of Natural
Resources, pursuant to Ohio R.C. Chapter 1509. (Ord. 89-47. Passed 5-24-89.)
   760.03 PERMIT APPLICATION; REVIEW.
   (a)   No person, firm or corporation shall, within the limits of the City,
drill a new oil or gas well, drill an existing oil or gas well any deeper,
reopen an oil or gas well, convert an oil or gas well to any use other than its
original purpose, or plug back an oil or gas well to a source of supply
different from the existing pool, without first having obtained a permit
(hereinafter referred to as "City permit") to do so issued from the City
Engineer or his designee.
   (b)   In order to obtain the permit required under this section, the
following shall be submitted to the City Engineer or his designee at least five
business days prior to the commencement of any activity described hereinabove:
       (1)   An exact and complete copy of a valid permit for the proposed
activity issued from the Chief of the Division of Oil and Gas of the Ohio
Department of Natural Resources pursuant to Ohio R.C. Chapter 1509, along with
an exact and complete copy of any application, plan, map and other
documentation filed therefor;
       (2)   A map or plan of the general area in which the activity will take
place, specifying any residences within 1000 feet of the site of the activity
and the proposed route of access to the activity site for motor vehicles and
equipment;
       (3)   A listing of the dates and times it is anticipated that site
preparation or drilling rig erection will take place;
       (4)   A permit fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000) which shall be
allocated for building inspection services;
       (5)   The road bond referred to in Section
760.05;
       (6)   A certificate of liability insurance indicating the City as an
"additional named insured" under the policy procured by the applicant; and
       (7)   Paid for advertising to be published in the Youngstown Vindicator
at least three times in the week prior to each drilling activity commencing;
       (8)   Site preparation and pre-drilling shall be done in daylight hours
only. Proper landscaping and fencing to be approved by the Zoning Analyst shall
be installed within thirty days after the drilling is completed;
       (9)   The Fire Department shall have access to the site; training for
the Fire Department personnel shall be given by permit holders for gas and oil
well emergencies, maps locating well-heads and separators shall be provided to
the Fire Chief and City Engineer. (Ord. 89-47. Passed 5-24-89.)
      (10)   The residents within 700 feet of the well shall be given notice of
the location, time of the drilling and shall be given the opportunity to be
included in this expansion of the statutory 500-foot radius requirement for
permission to drill and inclusion in payment of royalties, that is, the 500-
foot radius for the drilling unit is increased to 700 feet.
         (Ord. 89-382. Passed 7-18-89.)
   (c)   The City Engineer or his designee is hereby granted the authority to
limit the nighttime hours the person, firm or corporation may conduct site
preparation or drilling erection activities within the City limits, taking into
consideration the noise generated by such activities may have on residents of
the City living within 1000 feet of the activity site. The noise level shall
not exceed a decibel level of more than fifty-five decibels from 5:00 p.m. to
7:00 a.m. and seventy decibels during the day from 7:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. The
City Engineer or his designee is granted the additional authority to determine
the route of access for motor vehicles and equipment traveling to and from the
activity site which he believes will result in the least potential for damage
to City streets, avenues, alleys, lanes or public grounds and danger to
residents, pedestrians or traffic; provided, however, that the determination of
such access route by the City Engineer or his designee shall not unreasonably
delay, prevent, deny or preclude such person, firm or corporation from
commencing its drilling activities.
   The permitted hours of activities and the permitted access route determined
by the City Engineer or his designee shall be indicated on or attached to the
permit issued under this section.
   (d)   Upon completing his review of the application materials submitted in
accordance with this section and determining whether or not operational
limitations are necessary and the access route for motor vehicles and
equipment, the City Engineer or his designee shall issue the permit required
under this section to the person, firm or corporation that has made application
therefor. The City Engineer or his designee shall be required to complete his
review and make all determinations required within five business days of
receipt of all application materials submitted as required under this section.
(Ord. 89-47. Passed 5-24-89.)
   760.04 REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Regardless of whether an appropriate permit has been obtained from the
Chief of the Division of Oil and Gas of the Ohio Department of Natural
Resources, pursuant to Ohio R.C. Chapter 1509 and/or the City Engineer or his
designee, pursuant to this chapter, no person, firm or corporation shall:
      (1)   Engage in site preparation or drilling rig erection activities at
hours other than those permitted by the City Engineer or designee; and
      (2)   Fail to use the approved access route for ingress and egress to the
activity site indicated on the permit issued by the City Engineer or his
designee.
   (b)   No person, firm or corporation shall drill, construct, reopen,
convert, plug back, plug, use, operate, maintain, repair, abandon or remove
waste materials from any oil or gas wells within the limits of the City in such
a manner as to be injurious or dangerous to the health, safety, welfare or
property of individuals.
   (c)   There shall be no remaining contaminated land surrounding the well-
head. The procedure to insure this requirement shall be as follows:
      (1)   The top soil within 100 feet from the well-head shall be removed
and temporarily stored on site.
      (2)   The containment trench shall be lined as required in the Ohio
Administrative Code.
      (3)   After use of brine and other liquid is completed and disposed of,
the original topsoil shall be replaced in its former location.
   (d)   The distance from the well equipment and its appurtenances to any
inhabited structure shall be 200 feet.
(Ord. 89-47. Passed 5-24-89.)
   760.05 DAMAGES; FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY; BOND.
   No person, firm or corporation operating within the limits of the City,
pursuant to Ohio R.C. Chapter 1509 and/or this chapter shall cause damage to
any street, avenue, alley, lane or any public grounds or property within the
limits of the City by virtue of the operation or use of any motor vehicle or
equipment.
   To assure financial responsibility for repairs necessitated by violations of
this section, the applicant for the permit shall file with the City Engineer or
his designee a road bond from a surety company authorized to do business in the
State in an amount not less than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000), conditioned
on compliance with this section.
   Any bond obtained to comply with this section may be released after the
completion of drilling operations upon certification by the office of the City
Engineer that no damage has occurred to City streets, avenues, alleys, lanes or
any public grounds or property as a result of oil or gas well operations within
the City limits under the permit. (Ord. 89-47. Passed 5-24-89.)
   760.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm or corporation who violates, or fails to comply with, any
provision of this chapter, shall be fined not more than one thousand five
hundred dollars ($1,500). Each day any violation of any provision of this
chapter continues, shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 89-47. Passed 5-24-89.)
CHAPTER 761
Itinerant Retailers
761.01   License required.
761.02   License fee.
761.03   License transferability; revocation.
761.04   License requirements.
761.05   Itinerant retailer defined.
761.06   Badges.
761.07   License on person.
761.08   Display of license.
761.09   Exemption.
761.10   Prohibited conduct.
761.11   Denial, suspension and revocation.
761.12   Food itinerant retailers.
761.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
Home solicitation sales - see Ohio R.C. 1345.21 et seq.
Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716; BUS. REG. Ch.
779
Trespassing - see GEN. OFF.
541.05
Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
   761.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the various businesses, as defined in this
chapter, without first having secured from the Chief of Police a license to do
so. A separate license shall be required for each place, stand or vehicle
operated by the licensee.
(Ord. 10-197. Passed 6-16-10.)
   761.02 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for each license issued under this chapter shall be one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00) per year or fifty dollars ($50.00) per thirty day
period. Such license shall be issued by the Chief of Police and shall have
indicated thereon the dates for which such license is granted.
(Ord. 10-197. Passed 6-16-10.)
   761.03 LICENSE TRANSFERABILITY; REVOCATION.
   All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be void, if
transferred, and shall be subject to revocation by the Police Chief for
violation of any of the requirements of this chapter or if in the judgment of
the Police Chief such revocation is necessary for the preservation of the
public peace, health, safety or welfare.
(Ord. 10-197. Passed 6-16-10.)
   761.04 LICENSE REQUIREMENTS.
   No license shall be issued by the Chief of Police under this chapter unless
written verification is received from the Department of Planning and Zoning
that the retailing activity is permitted by the Youngstown Zoning Code on the
property which the itinerant retailer plans to conduct his activity. (Ord. 10-
197. Passed 6-16-10.)
   761.05 ITINERANT RETAILER DEFINED.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly dictates or requires a different meaning.
   (a)   "Itinerant retailer." A person or agent of a person who offers for
sale, barter, or exchange anything of value at any place in, upon, along, or
through any street, alley or other public place, or on private property. The
term "itinerant retailer" does not include an owner or operator of a business
located in a building or structure being used for a commercial or retail
purpose, nor to such owner or operator's activities adjacent to or abutting
such building or structure when items sold on property adjacent to or abutting
a commercial building or structure are the primary type of goods offered for
sale inside that commercial building or structure. The term "itinerant
retailer" shall not include persons peddling goods door to door.
   (b)   "Trailer" means any enclosed vehicle or structure designed for the
conduct of any business, profession, occupation or trade, or for use as a
selling or advertising device that is or may be mounted on wheels and used as a
conveyance on highways or streets by its own or other motive power.
      (Ord. 10-197. Passed 6-16-10.)
   761.06 BADGES.
   (a)   The grantee of the license shall procure from the Youngstown Police
Department one badge, the size and design of which shall be determined by the
Police Department from time to time. The Police Department shall have inscribed
or printed upon the badge the words “Itinerant Retailer No. _” and the dates of
issue and expiration. The badge shall not be transferred or assigned. All
grantees shall have this badge conspicuously displayed on their persons in such
a manner as to be easily seen while doing business. No person, other than the
grantee, shall make use of the badge.
   (b)    No grantee of a badge shall continue to use the same when for any
reason it has become so obscured as not to be easily read.
(Ord. 10-197. Passed 6-16-10.)
   761.07 LICENSE ON PERSON.
   (a)   No person shall operate as an itinerant retailer without clearly
displaying on his person a valid badge issued pursuant to this chapter.
   (b)   No person shall operate as an itinerant retailer on private property
belonging to another without possessing written permission from the property
owner. The itinerant retailer must have said written permission on his person
while engaging in the business of an itinerant retailer and produce it if it so
requested by any law enforcement officer.
(Ord. 10-197. Passed 6-16-10.)
   761.08 DISPLAY OF LICENSE.
   Every grantee of a license under this chapter shall, when so requested by a
law enforcement officer, produce such license for inspection.
(Ord. 10-197. Passed 6-16-10.)
   761.09 EXEMPTION.
   This chapter does not apply to Home Sales as defined in Section
 748.01.
(Ord. 10-197. Passed 6-16-10.)
   761.10 PROHIBITED CONDUCT.
   (a)   No merchandise shall be displayed on a public sidewalk or sold within
ten feet of a:
      (1)   Doorway or entranceway or within ten feet of prolongation of a
doorway or entranceway to the curbline;
      (2)   Crosswalk;
      (3)   Designated bus stop;
      (4)   Fire hydrant; or
      (5)   Curbcut.
   (b)   No merchandise shall be displayed on any utility pole, planter, tree,
trash container, public bench, or other sidewalk fixture.
   (c)   No merchandise shall be displayed or sold in any manner that blocks,
obstructs, or restricts the free passage of pedestrians in the lawful use of
sidewalks.
   (d)   Sidewalk vendors must contain their stand, including merchandise and
supplies, within an area no larger than eight feet by six feet. Itinerant
retailers selling from locations other than sidewalks shall have combined sales
and display areas no larger than twelve feet by twelve feet.
   (e)   No trailer may be placed on any sidewalk.
   (f)   No advertising, except the posting of prices, shall be permitted on or
by any stand or motor vehicle other than to identify merchandise offered for
sale or to identify itinerant retailer.
   (g)   No itinerant retailers shall operate within the boundaries of a
designated special event or public property without the express permission of
the sponsor of the general event. Itinerant retailers operating in special
events are exempt from the license requirement during the event. Designated
special events shall include only those events for which the written approval
of the Mayor has been obtained for the use of public property for the special
event. The Mayor may grant permission for the use of the public property for
special events sponsored by community service organizations and nonprofit
corporations. A map designating the boundaries of the public property being
utilized for the special event must be submitted to the Chief of Police after
the special event has been approved.
   (h)   No itinerant retailer shall operate in any one location for more than
three consecutive days.
   (i)   Itinerant retailers shall remove all equipment, vehicles and price
postings from their places of operation at the end of each day.
(Ord. 10-197. Passed 6-16-10.)
   761.11 DENIAL, SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION.
   Any license may be denied, suspended, or revoked in accordance with the
procedure contained in this article for any of the following causes:
   (a)   Fraud or misrepresentation contained in the application for the
license.
   (b)   Fraud or misrepresentation made in the course of carrying on the
business of vending.
   (c)   Conduct of the licensed business in such manner as to create a public
nuisance, or constitute a danger to the public health, safety, welfare or
morals.
   (d)   Conduct which is contrary to the provisions of this chapter.
      (Ord. 10-197. Passed 6-16-10.)
   761.12 FOOD ITINERANT RETAILERS.
   (a)   Food itinerant retailers cooking on open-flame grills on site must
provide fire retardant barriers between cooking device and pedestrians and
adjoining property.
   (b)   No more than one twenty-pound liquid petroleum cylinder may be
attached to the vehicle or appliance at any time. No spare liquid petroleum
cylinders may be kept within the peddling area as specified in Section
 761.10. The liquid petroleum cylinder shall be mounted in a well-ventilated
compartment attached to the vehicle.
   (c)   An ABC rated fire extinguisher of a five-pound or greater capacity
shall be mounted on the outside of the cart vehicle opposite the burner unit.
(Ord. 10-197. Passed 6-16-10.)
   761.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which no other penalty is
provided is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree for the first offense
and a misdemeanor of the first degree for each subsequent offense.
(Ord. 10-197. Passed 6-16-10.)
CHAPTER 762
Door to Door Solicitation and Peddling
762.01   Definitions.
762.02   Hours of peddling and solicitation required.
762.03   Peddling in residential districts.
762.04   Registration of credentials for peddlers; application fee.
762.05   Notice prohibiting peddling or solicitation.
762.06   Peddling in violation of notice.
762.07   False information.
762.08   Display of credentials; peddlers.
762.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Itinerant retailers - see BUS. REG. Ch.
761
   762.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the
context:
   (a)   "Peddling" means calling at residences without an invitation or
previous consent of the owner or occupant of such premises for the purpose of
any one or more of the following activities:
      (1)   Seeking for profit to obtain orders for the purchase of goods,
wares, merchandise, foodstuffs or services of any kind, character or
description whatever, for either present or future delivery;
      (2)   Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase
of insurance of any type, kind or character;
      (3)   Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals,
newspapers and every other kind or type of publication.
   (b)   "Solicitation" means:
      (1)   Seeking to obtain from an occupant of any residence an indication
of such occupant's belief in regard to any social, political or religious
matters;
      (2)   Seeking to obtain contributions or sell any goods, articles or
services of any kind for the support or benefit of any educational, civic,
philanthropic, charitable, religious or non-profit association, organization,
corporation or project;
      (3)   Seeking to influence the personal belief of the occupant of any
residence in regard to any social, political or religious matter; or
      (4)   Taking a poll or census by any person, firm or corporation, other
than a governmental body or agency thereof, and excluding commercial polls.
         (Ord. 10-196. Passed 6-16-10.)
   762.02 HOURS OF PEDDLING AND SOLICITATION REGULATED.
   No peddling or solicitation shall be conducted before 9:00 a.m. or after 5:
00 p.m.
(Ord. 10-196. Passed 6-16-10.)
   762.03 PEDDLING IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS.
   No person shall enter upon the lot or land of any residence for the purpose
of peddling as defined in Section
762.01 unless such person has registered and has in his possession the valid,
current registration issued in accordance with the provisions of Section
 762.04.
(Ord. 10-196. Passed 6-16-10.)
   762.04 REGISTRATION OF CREDENTIALS FOR PEDDLERS; APPLICATION FEE.
   (a)   Whoever desires to engage in peddling as defined in Section
762.01 shall register his credentials and shall submit in duplicate with the
Youngstown Police Chief a written application on a form to be provided by the
Youngstown Police Department, along with a valid driver's license or
identification card issued by the State of Ohio or any other state for
inspection and copying, correctly setting forth the following information:
      (1)   The full name, address, and social security number of the
applicant;
      (2)   Whether or not he or she uses any motor vehicle(s) in his or her
business, and if so, the make(s), model(s), year(s) and current registration
number(s) thereof;
      (3)   The name, address and phone number of his or her business or
employer, and a contact person therein;
      (4)   A brief description of the goods, wares, merchandise or services
involved;
         and
      (5)   Whether or not he or she has ever been convicted of any crime,
other than a traffic offense, and if so, the nature thereof and the penalty
therefor.
   (b)   Concurrently with the filing of the application, the applicant shall
pay a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) to the City of Youngstown to
compensate for the costs incident to the examination, registration and issuance
of stamped copies of credentials.
   (c)   Registration shall be approved after receipt of the completed
application unless:
      (1)   The applicant has provided false information in his or her
application; and/ or
      (2)   The applicant named on the application has been convicted of a
felony violation or misdemeanor violation as set forth in subsection (g) hereof
within the past five years.
   Such registration shall be stamped with the date of expiration which in each
case shall be the close of the current calendar year or six months, whichever
is later.
   (d)   Once issued, registration may be used only in conformity with the laws
of the City and the State of Ohio; may not be assigned or transferred; must be
carried by the peddler at all times; and may be revoked for any of the
following causes:
      (1)   The peddler named in the application or person preparing the
application on behalf of the peddler provided false information in the
application; and/ or
      (2)   The peddler is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor as set forth in
subsection (g) hereof.
   (e)   Possession of registration credentials shall not entitle the applicant
to enter upon any lot or land specified in Section
 762.05 between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. nor shall such credentials
be valid for the peddling of any goods or services not disclosed in the
original application.
   (f)   Any person who has not reached eighteen years of age shall be required
to have a parent, guardian or employer co-sign on the application.
   (g)   Any person who has been convicted of or who has plead guilty to any
criminal offense of the Ohio Revised Code, United States Code, or any other
substantially similar state or local code provisions that constitute any theft
or fraud offense, any offense of burglary, any offenses of violence, or any
offenses of any sex crime law or statute within the last five years is
prohibited from peddling within the City of Youngstown.
(Ord. 10-196. Passed 6-16-10.)
   762.05 NOTICE PROHIBITING PEDDLING OR SOLICITATION.
   Notice by the owner or occupant of any residence of the determination to
refuse to receive any uninvited peddlers or solicitors shall be given by
displaying a card, decal or sign, not less than two inches by three inches in
size nor more than one square foot in total surface area, upon or near the main
entrance door to the residence, indicating such determination by the owner or
occupant, containing the words "No Solicitors," "No Trespassing," or words of
similar import, with letters at least 1/3 of an inch in height. Any such sign
that complies with the requirements of this section shall be exempt from
additional or different requirements in the City of Youngstown Sign Code.
(Ord. 10-196. Passed 6-16-10.)
   762.06 PEDDLING IN VIOLATION OF NOTICE.
   No person shall go upon any premises and ring the bell or knock or create
any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of any
occupant of such residence for the purpose of peddling or solicitation in
defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the
provisions of Section
762.05, unless the peddler or solicitor is there upon the invitation of the
owner, lessee, or adult occupant of the premises.
(Ord. 10-196. Passed 6-16-10.)
   762.07 FALSE INFORMATION.
   No person shall make any false statement or give any false or misleading
information in the application required by Section
762.04.
(Ord. 10-196. Passed 6-16-10.)
   762.08 DISPLAY OF CREDENTIALS; PEDDLERS.
   (a)   Every holder of registered credentials, when engaged in peddling upon
any lot or land of any residence shall, upon the request of any owner or
occupant of a residence, present for examination his credentials issued
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter.
   (b)   Every holder of registered and stamped credentials shall prominently
display his or her credentials in a conspicuous place upon his or her person at
all times while peddling pursuant to this section.
   (c)   The Youngstown Police Department shall cause a weatherproof credential
of sufficient size and color to be given to each approved applicant herein.
(Ord. 10-196. Passed 6-16-10.)
   762.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which no other penalty is
provided, is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree for the first offense
and a misdemeanor of the first degree for each subsequent offense.
(Ord. 10-196. Passed 6-16-10.)
CHAPTER 763
Poolrooms and Billiard Parlors
763.01   License required.
763.02   License fee requirements.
763.03   Denial of license.
763.04   Public poolrooms and billiard parlors defined.
763.05   License application; fee.
763.06   Posting license; record; deposit of fees.
763.07   Window regulations.
763.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Gambling - see GEN. OFF.
517.02 et seq.
      Curfew - see GEN. OFF.
531.01
      Poolrooms and billiard parlors - see GEN. OFF.
531.03
   763.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the business of operating a poolroom or billiard
parlor without first having secured from the Mayor a license to do so, and
without paying to the Mayor, in advance, the amount of such license fee as
herein provided for each place operated by the licensee. (1967 Code §114.27)
   763.02 LICENSE FEE REQUIREMENTS.
   The license fee for the operation of a poolroom or billiard parlor shall be
payable in advance. The life of all licenses, except as otherwise provided,
issued under this chapter shall terminate at midnight on the night of December
31 in the year in which issued. Fees for all licenses that have less than one
year to run from date of issuance shall be computed on the quarter year amount
for the time which the license has to run before the time of its expiration.
All licenses shall be void, if transferred, and shall be subject to revocation
by the Mayor for misconduct of the party holding the same. (1967 Code §114.28)
   763.03 DENIAL OF LICENSE.
   No license shall be granted to any person or persons who have, within five
years preceding the application for license, been convicted of any offense,
felony or misdemeanor which involved moral turpitude, violence or the use of a
deadly weapon, or prostitution laws or ordinances. No license to engage in or
conduct the business of a public pool or billiard room, as defined in this
chapter, shall be granted to any person or persons not a citizen or citizens of
the United States, and no license shall be granted to any corporation to engage
in the business as defined in this chapter unless a majority of the
stockholders of the corporation are citizens of the United States. (Ord. 78030.
Passed 6-5-68.)
   763.04 PUBLIC POOLROOMS AND BILLIARD PARLORS DEFINED.
   "Public poolrooms and billiard parlors", as used in this chapter, means
places or rooms where pool tables or billiard tables are maintained and
operated for the use of the public generally or where a charge is made or
received for playing upon the tables. (1967 Code §114.37)
   763.05 LICENSE APPLICATION; FEE.
   Every person desiring to open and keep open, a public billiard or poolroom
as defined in Section
763.04 must make application to the Mayor for a license therefor and must give
two responsible citizens as references as to his reputation and pay a license
fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) per year for the first table, ten dollars
($10.00) for the second table and five dollars ($5.00) for each additional
table. (Ord. 77659. Passed 3-7-68.)
   763.06 POSTING LICENSE; RECORD; DEPOSIT OF FEES.
   The license shall be hung in a conspicuous place in the billiard or
poolroom. The Mayor shall keep a record of all licenses issued and deposit all
fees with the Director of Finance.
(1967 Code §114.39)
   763.07 WINDOW REGULATIONS.
   No person owning or conducting any billiard or poolroom or public place
where billiards or pool are played, shall, at any hour of the day or night,
obstruct the windows or the glass of the doors in the room or rooms where such
playing of billiards or pool is carried on, by any shaded blind, screen,
lattice or other obstruction or covering of any kind whatsoever, or place or
allow to remain any screen, blind, shade, lattice or any obstruction or
covering of any kind whatsoever which may obstruct or tend to obstruct the
plain and free view of all parts of the interior of the poolroom or billiard
room in such house or place from the entrance thereof and from any public
sidewalk, street or alley upon which the house or place fronts or abuts. Any
person owning or conducting pool or billiard rooms or public places where
billiards or pool are played and having such screens, shades, blinds or other
obstructions or covering hereinbefore mentioned, shall remove the same and keep
the same removed during all hours of the day or night. The room shall be
constructed or erected so that it shall have at least one transparent glass
therein on each side of the place fronting or abutting on a public sidewalk,
street or alley. The glass in the windows or doors are to be not less than
eighteen by twenty-four inches in size, to be placed between four and one-half
and six feet above the surface of the sidewalk, street or alley through which a
free and unobstructed view may be had of the interior of such room from such
sidewalk, street or alley. (1967 Code §114.40)
   763.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for the first offense, a misdemeanor of the fourth degree for a
second offense and a misdemeanor of the third degree for a subsequent offense
and the billiard parlor or poolroom shall be abated as a public nuisance.
   For the fine and costs in a prosecution under this chapter, the billiard
tables and fixtures at the place where the violation occurred are liable on
execution without exemption.
CHAPTER 765
Public Garages and Parking Lots
765.01   Purpose.
765.02   Definitions.
765.03   License required.
765.04   License application.
765.05   License issuance; renewal.
765.06   Signs.
765.07   Employees.
765.08   Maintenance of parking facility and surroundings.
765.09   Revocation or suspension of license.
765.10   Appeals.
765.11   Non-conforming parking facilities.
765.99   Penalty.
   765.01 PURPOSE.
   It is recognized that Youngstown's central business district is
characterized by the highest levels of vehicular traffic, pedestrian traffic
and parking demand. These circumstances require that the highest standards for
parking facility operation be applied to facilities located within the central
business district. These regulations are established to ensure that licensed
parking facilities are furnished with amenities that provide customers with
accurate, useful and legible information regarding operational matters. The
central business district is defined as The Mahoning River on the South, South
Avenue, Commerce Street to Watt Street on the East, Wood Street on the North to
Belmont Avenue on the West and as shown below in Figure 1.
Figure 1: Central Business District Parking License Required District
 
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/7b082dce1c2b575e8f1a3b62a47a657ef6d863e7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-4328.jpg]
(Ord. 15-253. Passed 9-16-15.)
   765.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this Chapter, the following words are defined and shall
have the meaning ascribed to them as hereafter set forth:
   (a)    Parking Garage: Any structure or part thereof that storing of motor
vehicles for a fee is open to the public for special events, daily or monthly
fee.
   (b)    Parking Lot: Any lot or part thereof that storing of motor vehicles
for a fee is open to the public for special events, daily or monthly fee.
   (c)    Parking Space: An off-street storage area for the parking of one
motor vehicle and not less than 8.5 feet wide and 18 feet long.
      (Ord. 15-253. Passed 9-16-15.)
   765.03 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of storing motor
vehicles for a fee in a building or a lot within the designated area identified
in Section
765.01 unless and until licensed in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter.
(Ord. 15-253. Passed 9-16-15.)
   765.04 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Every applicant for a license to operate a public garage or parking lot
shall make application in writing to the Director of Finance, which application
shall set forth the following information:
   (a)    The name and address of the applicant, and if a partnership, the
names and addresses of all partners, and if a corporation, the name, date and
state under which incorporated, and the name and address of the statutory
agent;
   (b)    An accurately scaled and dimensioned site plan and elevation drawing
(s) showing the configuration of entrances, exits, aisles and spaces;
identifying the right-of-way, curbs and sidewalks, signage, landscaping, wheel
stops, and screening materials; and indicating the dimensions of all such
elements;
   (c)    The hours during which motor vehicles may be stored and the hours
during which the premises will be served by an attendant;
   (d)    Such other information as the Director deems pertinent or necessary
to carry into effect the provisions of this chapter.
      (Ord. 15-253. Passed 9-16-15.)
   765.05 LICENSE ISSUANCE; RENEWAL.
   (a)    Public Garages. Upon receipt of an application for a license to
operate a public garage, and payment of the required fee by division (f) of
this section, the Director of Finance shall issue the license on a form
prescribed by him for that purpose. No license shall be issued except to an
applicant for a property which is in compliance with the terms of this chapter
and is also in compliance with the Building Code of the State of Ohio.
   (b)    Parking Lots. Upon receipt of an application for a license to operate
a parking lot, the Director of Finance shall transmit the application to the
City Planning Commission to determine whether the facility in question complies
with the substantive provision of this chapter and meets the requirements of
Chapter
1104 of the City of Youngstown Redevelopment Code regarding signage, screening,
landscaping, maintenance and operating standards.
   (c)    Issuance and Renewal. All licenses issued under this section shall be
issued for a period of one (1) year commencing January 1. Licenses may be
renewed if an application for renewal containing the information listed in
Section
765.04 is submitted. Applications for renewal shall be accompanied by the
required site plan and elevation drawings only when changes in the parking lot
render the previously submitted site plan or elevation drawings inaccurate.
   (d)    License Extension. If an application for a license renewal has been
submitted in accordance with the provisions of this chapter prior to an
existing license expiration, the Director of Finance shall extend the existing
license on a month-by-month basis until the review and approval has occurred.
   (e)    Applicability to Premises. A license issued under this section shall
apply only to the premises described in the application and a separate
application and license shall be required for each noncontiguous site. Licenses
shall not be assignable or transferable.
   (f)    License Fees. Each application for a new or renewal license shall be
accompanied by a fee of $25.00 for a parking garage, $50.00 for a parking lot
with a capacity of 100 cars or less, and $75.00 for a parking lot with a
capacity of more than 100 cars.
(Ord. 15-253. Passed 9-16-15.)
   765.06 SIGNS.
   These regulations are established to ensure provision of signs which clearly
and effectively identify parking available to visitors seeking daily or other
short-term parking. Signage is required for the following:
   (a)    Visitor-Oriented Parking Facilities. Parking facilities that are
available to the general public on an hourly, daily or special event basis
shall display a sign or signs, visible from each vehicular entrance displaying
the international parking symbol, displayed as a white letter "p" at least
fourteen (14) inches in height, placed on a purple (PMS #2685) circular
background, a minimum of twenty-two (22) inches in diameter.
   (b)    Display of Rates. Each parking facility shall be furnished with signs
readable from each vehicular entrance, displaying all parking rates applicable
at any given time. When multiple rates are applicable at a given time, the
display shall include, at a minimum, the lowest and highest rates. All rates
shall be displayed in numerals which are the same size for each rate. Rates
shall be displayed a minimum height of five (5) inches for dollar amounts and
three (3) inches for cents.
   (c)    Special Event or Special Rate Parking. Information regarding flat
fees for special event parking or other special time-period parking shall be
displayed on a free-standing sign with the word "Event" accompanied by the
applicable rate.
      (Ord. 15-253. Passed 9-16-15.)
   765.07 EMPLOYEES.
   While on duty at the parking facility, each employee shall wear a uniform or
badge, provided by the parking facility operator, identifying the individual as
an employee of the subject operator.
(Ord. 15-253. Passed 9-16-15.)
   765.08 MAINTENANCE OF PARKING FACILITY AND SURROUNDINGS.
   Each operator of a parking facility shall keep the sidewalk surrounding the
parking facility free from dirt, ice, sleet and snow and shall keep the
sidewalk and driveways in a safe condition for the travel of pedestrians. The
operator shall at all times be required to keep the lot in good order and
condition. All lots shall have a permanent hard surface and be free from
nuisance.
(Ord. 15-253. Passed 9-16-15.)
   765.09 REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE.
   The Director of Finance may at any time revoke or suspend licenses granted
under the authority of this chapter, for failure to comply with the terms of
this chapter.
(Ord. 15-253. Passed 9-16-15.)
   765.10 APPEALS.
   In case of refusal to issue a license or of the revocation or suspension of
a license by the Director of Finance, the applicant or license may appeal from
such order to the Board of Zoning Appeals.
(Ord. 15-253. Passed 9-16-15.)
   765.11 NON-CONFORMING PARKING FACILITIES.
   Parking facilities in operation at the time of passage that do not comply
with all of the design standards maybe granted a one year provisional license.
No provisional licenses shall be extended beyond one year from the passage of
this chapter.
(Ord. 15-253. Passed 9-16-15.)
   765.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a
minor misdemeanor and fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each
day that the violation continues may be treated as a separate offense.
(Ord. 15-253. Passed 9-16-15.)
CHAPTER 767
Public Dances
767.01   License required.
767.02   License fee requirements.
767.03   Denial of license.
767.04   Public dance defined.
767.05   Dance license fees.
767.06   Annual permits and exemptions for charitable, religious and fraternal
bodies.
767.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate dancing academies or public ballrooms - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
Intoxicating liquor in dance hall - see Ohio R.C. 4399.14
Loud and disturbing noises - see GEN. OFF.
509.10
   767.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person shall engage in the business of conducting a public dance
without first having secured from the Mayor or his designee, a license to do
so, and without paying to the Mayor or his designee, in advance, the amount of
such license fee as herein provided for each place operated by the licensee.
   (b)   Applications for public dances shall be made to the Finance Department
on such forms as may be prescribed and shall contain such information as is
reasonably necessary to a fair determination of whether a permit should be
issued. The permit may be refused or canceled if the information contained in
the application is found to be false, misleading or incomplete in any material
detail.
   (c)   The completed application form signed by the chairperson or persons
shall be submitted to the Finance Department at least two weeks in advance of
the scheduled public dance date. (Ord. 04-290. Passed 11-17-04.)
   767.02 LICENSE FEE REQUIREMENTS.
   The license fee for conducting a public dance shall be payable in advance.
The life of all licenses, except as otherwise provided, issued under this
chapter shall terminate at midnight on the night of December 31 in the year in
which issued. Fees for all licenses that have less than one year to run from
date of issuance shall be computed on the quarter year amount for the time
which the license has to run before the time of its expiration. All licenses
shall be void, if transferred, and shall be subject to revocation by the Mayor,
or his designee, for misconduct of the party holding the same. (Ord. 1993-208.
Passed 3-31-93.)
   767.03 DENIAL OF LICENSE.
   No license shall be granted to any person or persons who have, within five
years preceding the application for license, been convicted of any offense,
felony or misdemeanor which involved moral turpitude, violence or the use of a
deadly weapon, or prostitution laws or ordinances. No license to engage in or
conduct the business of a public dance, as defined in this chapter shall be
granted to any person or persons not a citizen or citizens of the United
States, and no license shall be granted to any corporation to engage in the
business as defined in this chapter unless a majority of the stockholders of
the corporation are citizens of the United States.
(Ord. 78030. Passed 6-5-68.)
   767.04 PUBLIC DANCE DEFINED.
   (a)   "Public dance", as used in this chapter, means a dance which is open
to the public generally or to members or a dance for which an admission is
charged, demanded or received and which begins no earlier than 3:00 p.m. and
ends by 12:00 p.m. midnight the same day, unless extended or authorized by the
Ohio Department of Liquor Control in granting a liquor permit beyond 12:00 p.m.
midnight.
   (b)   All other public dances not meeting the definition in subsection (a)
above, are prohibited.
(Ord. 1993-208. Passed 3-31-93.)
   767.05 DANCE LICENSE FEES.
   The license fee to be charged and paid for public dances as defined in
Section
767.04 shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year for public dances
conducted or carried on in any place where the management or operators do not
permit, accept, receive or demand any minimum admission or cover charge, or any
dancing charge; provided, however, that in the event the holder of the license,
after the issuance thereof, desires to permit, accept, receive or demand any of
the charges upon any day or night during the period for which the annual
license was issued, an additional license fee in the amount of fifty dollars
($50.00) shall be charged and paid for each such day or night.
   The license fee to be charged and paid for all other public dances as
defined in Section
767.04 shall be the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for one day or one
night; two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per month; seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for six months; one thousand dollars ($1,000) per year.
(Ord. 1993-208. Passed 3-31-93.)
   767.06 ANNUAL PERMITS AND EXEMPTIONS FOR CHARITABLE, RELIGIOUS AND FRATERNAL
BODIES.
   The Mayor, or his designee, is hereby authorized to issue annual permits to
churches and non- profit organizations, designated as Internal Revenue Code
Section 501(c)(3) organizations and in good standing as such with the Ohio
Secretary of State, desiring to hold dances on their premises, such dances
being for the benefit of the respective church or above described non-profit
organization.
   No fee shall be charged for any permit issued as provided in the above
paragraph, but no such dance shall be held within the City limits unless, prior
to holding the same, such permit is obtained from the Mayor, or his designee.
   The permits shall be obtained on or about January 1 of each year and shall
terminate on December 31 thereafter.
(Ord. 1993-208. Passed 3-3-93.)
   767.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for the first offense and a misdemeanor of the fourth degree for
each subsequent offense.
CHAPTER 771
Real Estate Sales
771.01   Regulating advertising.
771.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
False advertising - see GEN. OFF.
