   771.01 REGULATING ADVERTISING.
   No person, firm or corporation offering for sale real estate within the
corporate limits of the City shall by way of newspaper advertisement, radio
announcement, printed flyer, word of mouth, or any other method or medium of
advertisement, misrepresent the permitted uses of such real estate offered for
sale as defined by the Zoning Ordinance of the City.
   Misrepresentation as used in this chapter shall be as defined in Section
545.01 of the General Offenses Code. (Ord. 87875. Passed 6-19-74.)
   771.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the third degree.
CHAPTER 775
Service Stations
775.01   Storage of commercial waste.
775.02   Parking and storage of abandoned or inoperable motor vehicles.
775.03   Enforcement.
775.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Self-service - see Ohio R.C. 3741.14
Abandoned - see Ohio R.C. 3791.11 et seq.
   775.01 STORAGE OF COMMERCIAL WASTE.
   (a) Definition. "Waste", as referred to in this section, is synonymous with
"refuse", and means worthless matter, rubbish, scum or leavings, rags, wool,
cotton, paper and other such absorbent materials or composition thereof as are
used in wiping, cleaning and removing of grease, oils, gasoline, solvents,
additives and compounds in any commercial business or operation connected with
a service station.
   (b) Storage Area. No operation, owner, proprietor and/or lessee of any
automotive service station located within the City shall cause, permit or allow
any commercial waste to accumulate in an unhealthy or unsanitary manner upon
such premises. Commercial waste shall be stored within a bulk waste container
situated within a permanent screen wall located in such a manner as to be
screened from the view of those outside the property and in such a manner as to
be accessible to bulk waste container pick-up vehicles. This facility shall be
maintained in a sanitary and healthful manner as not to be harmful or offensive
to those on or outside the property. (Ord. 86851. Passed 11-21-73.)
   775.02 PARKING AND STORAGE OF ABANDONED OR INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES.
   (a)   Definitions.
      (1)   "Abandoned motor vehicle" means a motor vehicle that is extensively
damaged, or with parts missing, whose value does not exceed one hundred dollars
($100.00); is more than three years old; is without current license plates; and
is parked or stored upon private property more than seventy-two hours, or
parked or stored upon public property more than forty-eight hours.
      (2)   "Inoperable motor vehicle" means a motor vehicle apparently
inoperable and/or extensively damaged or with parts missing, and/or parked or
stored on private property over seventy-two hours, or on public property over
forty-eight hours.
   No motor vehicle, wrecked or extensively damaged or with its component parts
missing, or otherwise inoperable or abandoned, or such other inoperable
motorized equipment shall be parked or stored upon the service station premises
for a period in excess of seventy-two hours, except within the service station
building. (Ord. 86851. Passed 11-21-73.)
   775.03 ENFORCEMENT.
   The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the Police Department.
(Ord. 86851. Passed 11-21-73.)
   775.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for the first offense and a misdemeanor of the fourth degree for
each subsequent offense. Each day of continued violation shall constitute a
separate offense.
CHAPTER 777
Soft Drink Sales
777.01   Definition.
777.02   License required.
777.03   Prerequisites for issuance.
777.04   License fees.
777.05   License termination date.
777.06   License transferability; revocation.
777.07   Exemptions.
777.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Soft drink labeling and adulteration - see Ohio R.C. 913.25 et seq.
   777.01 DEFINITION.
   "Soft drink places" means places where dairy beverages are to be consumed on
the premises where sold, and places wherein grain beverages are sold containing
not more than one-half of one percent (.5%) of alcohol by volume, and where
pop, carbonated drinks, soda water and fruit juice drinks are sold, intended
for consumption either on or off the premises. (1967 Code §116.26)
   777.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the operation or conduct of a soft drink place as
defined in Section
777.01 without first having secured a license to do so from the Mayor, paying
the Mayor, in advance, the amount of such fee as provided in Section
777.04 for each place operated or conducted by the licensee. (1967 Code §16.27)
   777.03 PREREQUISITES FOR ISSUANCE.
   No license shall be granted to any person who has, within twelve months
preceding application for license, been convicted of any offense, felony or
misdemeanor which prosecution and conviction grew out of or arose from a
violation of the liquor, gambling or prostitution laws or ordinances. No
license to engage in or conduct the business of a soft drink place, as defined
in this chapter, shall be granted to any person who is not a citizen of the
United States, and no license shall be granted to any corporation to engage in
any of the various businesses and professions as defined in Section
777.01 unless a majority of the stockholders of the corporation are citizens of
the United States. (1967 Code §116.28)
   777.04 LICENSE FEES.
   The license fee to be charged and paid for in advance for any and all soft
drink places shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per year, or any part thereof. (1967
Code §116.29)
   777.05 LICENSE TERMINATION DATE.
   All licenses issued under this chapter shall terminate at 12:00 midnight on
the night of December 31 in the year in which issued. (1967 Code §116.30)
   777.06 LICENSE TRANSFERABILITY; REVOCATION.
   All licenses shall be void, if transferred, and shall be subject to
revocation by the Mayor if, in his judgment, the revocation is necessary for
the preservation of the public peace, health, safety or welfare. (1967 Code
§116.31)
   777.07 EXEMPTIONS.
   Sections
777.01 to
777.06 shall not apply to or affect drug stores where a pharmacist, duly
licensed by the State, is at all times employed or in control. It is the intent
and purpose of this chapter to exempt such drug stores from the license
provisions herein. (1967 Code §116.32)
   777.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for the first offense and a misdemeanor of the fourth degree for
each subsequent offense. Each day's continued violation shall constitute a
separate offense.
CHAPTER 779
Soliciting Funds
779.01   Registration.
779.02   Certificate issuance; revocation.
779.03   Nuisance.
779.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
Trespass - see GEN. OFF.
541.05
Theft by deception - see GEN. OFF.
545.05
Peddlers - see BUS. REG. Ch.
761
   779.01 REGISTRATION.
   No person shall engage in the solicitation of funds, contributions,
donations, pledges, subscriptions of money, property of any kind or value, or
seek information for such funds, without first having registered with the
Office of the Mayor. The registrant shall give his complete identification, his
signature, the name of his employer or organization and the proposed method of
operation in the City. (Ord. 88248. Passed 9-18-74.)
   779.02 CERTIFICATE ISSUANCE; REVOCATION.
   Each such applicant shall show evidence of good character, shall pay the fee
provided and shall be furnished a certificate indicating dates of validity of
such certificate. Each person shall at all times while soliciting in the City
carry upon his person such certificate and shall exhibit it whenever required
to do so by any police officer or by any person solicited. Such certificate may
be revoked by the Mayor or Chief of Police because of any violation of City
ordinances or laws of the State. (Ord. 88248. Passed 9-18-74.)
   779.03 NUISANCE.
   The practice of going in and upon private residences in the City, or
soliciting funds anywhere within the City without first requesting or being
invited to do so by the owner or owners, occupant or occupants of such private
residences, or places of occupancy or business, for the purpose of soliciting
funds is declared to be a nuisance. (Ord. 88248. Passed 9-18-74.)
   779.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the third degree.
CHAPTER 785
Taxicabs and Vehicles for Hire
785.01   Definitions.
785.02   State permit or City license required.
785.03   Chapter application to motorcycle operators.
785.04   Bond or liability insurance.
785.05   Agreement to pay judgment in of bond or insurance policy.
785.06   Taxicab rates.
785.07   Trunks and light baggage rates.
785.08   Going or returning empty.
785.09   Charge for minor children.
785.10   Receipt.
785.11   Additional passengers.
785.12   Driver to remain in driver's seat.
785.13   Cruising.
785.14   Person in charge of vehicle.
785.15   Information to be displayed on outside of vehicle.
785.16   Information to be displayed inside vehicle.
785.17   Solicitation of business.
785.18   Interior lights; curtains.
785.19   Direct and safe route.
785.20   Signal light.
785.21   Condition of vehicles.
785.22   Taxicab stands.
785.23   Fees generally.
785.24   Licenses generally.
785.25   Operator's license.
785.26   License for vehicle.
785.27   Driver's licenses.
785.28   Motorcycle license.
785.29   Taximeters.
785.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Chauffeur's license not required - see Ohio R.C. 4501.01(u)
Operation by minor prohibited - see Ohio R.C. 4507.321
Operation and equipment - see
TRAF. CODE
   785.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a) "Taxicab" means a vehicle used in carrying passengers for hire, the rate
for which is computed by the distance traveled and which follows no fixed or
prescribed route or schedule.
   (b) "Taxicab driver" means a person who drives or operates a motor-driven
conveyance which performs service similar to the cab or hackney carriage, held
for hire at designated places, for a fare proportioned to the length of the
trips of the several passengers to be carried to destinations without regard to
any route adopted or uniformly conformed to by the operator.
   (c) "Taximeter" means any instrument or device, attached to a vehicle,
designed or intended mechanically to measure and record the distance traveled,
the time such vehicle is in waiting and the amount of extras, upon which record
the fare to be charged shall be indicated, by figures or designs. (1967 Code
§117.01)
   (d) "Motorcycle" means every motor vehicle, other than a tractor, having a
saddle for the use of the operator and designed to travel on not more than
three wheels in contact with the ground, including but not limited to, motor
vehicles known as "motor-driven cycle", "motor scooter" or "motorcycle" without
regard to weight or brake horsepower. (ORC 4511.01(C))
   785.02 STATE PERMIT OR CITY LICENSE REQUIRED.
   The operation of motor vehicles, carrying passengers for hire, or the
leasing or renting of motorcycles (two-wheeled motor vehicles) by anyone, is
prohibited within the City, except when operation of such motor vehicles,
including leased or rented motorcycles, is by virtue of permit, issued by the
State Public Utilities Commission, by ordinance or under a City-issued license.
(1967 Code §117.02)
   785.03 CHAPTER APPLICATION TO MOTORCYCLE OPERATORS.
   Provisions of this chapter shall apply to all persons while operating or in
charge of any motorcycle leased or rented, whether as owner, agent, employee or
operator.
(1967 Code §117.03)
   785.04 BOND OR LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   No person shall operate a taxicab, rented automobile or rented motorcycle
business or permit such vehicles to be operated without a license. No license
for such business shall be issued under this chapter until and unless the
applicant for the license deposits with the Risk Manager:
   (a)   A bond of the applicant with a solvent and responsible surety company,
authorized under the law, as surety thereof, acceptable to and approved by the
Risk Manager. The bond shall be conditioned so that the applicant shall pay all
final judgments recovered against him for injury to one person up to the sum of
one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) and three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000) for injury to more than one person, and one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000) property damage in any one accident during the operation of the
taxicab, rented automobile, or rented motorcycle of the applicant.
      An applicant seeking a license to operate taxicabs or rented automobiles
shall file a bond in amounts as follows:
 
Number of Vehicles Amount of Bond
0 to 5             $11,000.00
6 to 10            15,000.00
11 to 15           20,000.00
16 to 25           25,000.00
26 to 50           30,000.00
51 to 100          40,000.00
      The bond shall contain a further provision obligating the surety company
to give thirty days' written notice before cancellation of such bond to the
Risk Manager, the license to expire on the lapse or termination of the bond; or
   (b)   A policy or certificate of liability insurance for each taxicab,
rented motorcycle or rented automobile for which a license is sought,
acceptable to and approved by the Risk Manager indemnifying the applicant in
the sum of at least minimum State requirements for injury to one person and
minimum State requirements for injury to more than one person and minimum State
requirements for property damage in any one accident through the operation of
the taxicab, rented automobile or rented motorcycle of the applicant. The
policy shall further contain a clause obligating the surety company to give
thirty days' written notice to the Risk Manager before cancellation of the
policy, the license to expire upon the lapse or termination of the policy of
insurance.
   (c)   The bond or policy of insurance shall contain a provision for a
continuing liability thereunder to the full amount thereof, notwithstanding any
recovery thereon. If at any time, in the judgment of the Risk Manager, the bond
or policy is not sufficient for any cause, the Risk Manager may require the
owner of the taxicab, rented automobile or rented motorcycle to replace the
bond or policy with another approved by the Risk Manager. (Ord. 94620. Passed
6-1-77.)
   785.05 AGREEMENT TO PAY JUDGMENT IN LIEU OF BOND OR INSURANCE POLICY.
   In lieu of the surety bonds or policies of insurance required by Section
785.04, the applicant or licensee may enter into an agreement with the City, to
be prepared to the satisfaction of the Law Director, that such applicant or
licensee shall pay all final judgments recovered against the applicant,
licensee and the driver of such taxicab or rented automobile or any of them
within the limits set forth in Section
785.04(a). Such limits shall be construed, however, to limit the liability of
such applicant, licensee and the driver, or any of them, only for the purpose
of such agreement.
   Agreements shall be secured by the deposit by the applicant or licensee of
cash or obligations of the United States Government, which shall be an amount
equal to fifty percent (50%) of the amount of the bond required by Section
785.04(a). Cash or collateral so deposited shall be the property of and subject
to the control of the City as trustee under the conditions of and for the
purposes of the agreement. However, in case of discontinuance of the operation
of taxicabs or rented automobiles or the subsequent substitution by any
licensee with the consent of the City of the bonds or policies of insurance
required in the preceding section in lieu of such agreement, an appraisal shall
be made of all claims pending against the licensee and a sufficient amount of
such cash or collateral deposited shall be retained as will guarantee the
payment of such claims. The balance of the fund, from time to time, shall be
returned to the licensee or his proper agent in proportion to the amount that
it shall be shown upon satisfactory proof that outstanding claims have been
paid or satisfied.
   In case of dispute over such appraisal or the determination of the amount to
be retained by the City, the matter shall be submitted for arbitration to a
judge of the Court of Common Pleas of the County, whose decision shall be
binding upon all parties.
   The City shall not be obligated to pay interest upon funds so deposited, nor
shall the City be entitled to the accruals upon any collateral deposited under
such agreement so long as there is no default on the obligation of the licensee
under such agreement.
   In the event that the applicant for a license or the renewal thereof, or any
licensee thereunder shall elect to take advantage of the provisions of this
section, he shall be entitled to a cancellation and release of any bond or
policy of insurance theretofore furnished under the provisions of Section
785.04, and the Law Director shall cause the cancellation and releases to be
executed and delivered to him. (1967 Code §117.05)
   785.06 TAXICAB RATES.
   No person owning, operating or controlling any motor vehicle or taxicab
shall make any charge for a fare unless such fare has been determined solely by
the use of a taximeter and is based upon the following rates:
(a) For the first 1/10 mile or fraction thereof  $1.50
(b) For each additional 1/10 mile or fraction    .10
(c) For each six minute waiting                  1.20
(d) Minimum charge per trip                      2.50
(e) Extra Charges:
    Extra passengers (each over one)             .50
    Extra stops (pickup or discharge passengers) .50
    Trunks, footlockers                          2.00
    Grocery and laundry bags 1 to 5              1.00
    Grocery and laundry bags 6 to 10             2.00
   No charge shall be made for the time lost through interruption of street
traffic or through the inefficiency of the vehicle or its driver, or for time
between a premature arrival in response to a call and the hour for which the
vehicle was ordered. When passengers for a different destination are taken in
addition to the party first hiring the taxicab or automobile for hire as above
provided such passenger may be charged upon the same basis as those originally
hiring the conveyance and this shall apply to each person or party bound for
separate and distinctly different destination, unless some members of a
distinct party shall desire to be discharged at some nearer or closer point
than that to which the other member or members of his distinct party is bound.
In this event, the party so discharged shall, at all times, be considered a
member of the party, and therefore the extra charge of fifty cents (50¢) only
applies to him/her.
(Ord. 87-274. Passed 6-3-87.)
   785.07 TRUNKS AND LIGHT BAGGAGE RATES.
   (a) The owner or driver of a taxicab or automobile for hire may make a
charge of one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) for each trunk known as a
"footlocker trunk" and for all other trunks, he may negotiate a charge with the
passenger concerning the charge. The owner or driver shall have the right to
refuse carrying baggage of a size beyond the capacity of one man (the taxi
driver) to manage, handle or move.
   (b) No charge shall be made for the first two pieces of luggage or baggage
carried by hand, but there shall be a charge of twenty-five cents (25¢) each
for all pieces in excess thereof. (1967 Code §117.07)
   785.08 GOING OR RETURNING EMPTY.
   No charge shall be made by the driver or operator of a taxicab or automobile
for hire either going or returning empty from a call. (1967 Code §117.08)
   785.09 CHARGE FOR MINOR CHILDREN.
   No charge shall be made by the driver or operator of a taxicab or automobile
for hire for children under five years of age when accompanied by a person
paying fare.
(1967 Code §117.09)
   785.10 RECEIPT.
   It shall be the duty of each driver of such taxicab or automobile for hire
to furnish to each user of such taxicab or automobile for hire, at the time of
discharging such passenger, a receipt showing the name of owner, driver's
number of license of taxicab, the amount of money received, the distance
traveled and also the points at which the passenger was taken on and point of
destination. (1967 Code §117.10)
   785.11 ADDITIONAL PASSENGERS.
   No driver or operator of any taxicab or automobile for hire having a
passenger therein shall, without the consent of such passenger or of the person
who first engaged the vehicle, convey any other person therein. (1967 Code
§117.11)
   785.12 DRIVER TO REMAIN IN DRIVER'S SEAT.
   The chauffeur or driver of any taxicab or automobile for hire shall remain
on the driver's seat inside his vehicle at all times when the vehicle is
standing upon the public streets. Nothing in this section shall be held to
prohibit the driver from alighting to the street or sidewalk for the purpose of
assisting a passenger into or out of such vehicle. (1967 Code §117.12)
   785.13 CRUISING.
   No driver or chauffeur of a taxicab or automobile for hire shall seek
employment by repeatedly or persistently driving his vehicle to and from, or
before, any hotel, theater, railroad station or other place of public
gathering, or by otherwise interfering with the proper and orderly passage to,
or egress from, any such place, or by driving his vehicle about the streets for
the purpose of soliciting business. (1967 Code §117.13)
   785.14 PERSON IN CHARGE OF VEHICLE.
   Not more than one licensed person shall be in charge of or ride in any such
taxicab or automobile kept for hire. (1967 Code §117.14)
   785.15 INFORMATION TO BE DISPLAYED ON OUTSIDE OF VEHICLE.
   (a) Any taxicab or automobile for hire shall at all times carry on the
outside of both front doors a sign bearing the name of the owner of the vehicle
and the City license number therefor. The letters and figures used in this sign
shall not be less than two inches square.
(1967 Code §117.15)
   (b) In addition the City license tag shall be placed on the vehicle in a
spot designated by the Police Department.
   785.16 INFORMATION TO BE DISPLAYED INSIDE VEHICLE.
   There shall be posted in a conspicuous place in a frame, with a transparent
cover, on the inside of each licensed taxicab or automobile kept for hire, a
card to be supplied by the Mayor at the time of the issuance of the license,
which card shall contain in plain, legible type, the number of license, the
rate of fare, a reference to this chapter by number, and such extracts from
this chapter as the Mayor may determine. (1967 Code §117.16)
   785.17 SOLICITATION OF BUSINESS.
   No driver or chauffeur of any taxicab or automobile for hire, nor any other
person shall, while upon the public streets or highways of the City, solicit
patrons or passengers for such vehicle in any other way than in an ordinary
tone of voice from the seat of his vehicle and by the display of a sign
attached to his vehicle, and such sign shall not be more than eight inches
square in size. It shall be unlawful for any owner, driver, chauffeur or agent
of any, to solicit patronage at or about a saloon or grillroom. (1967 Code
§117.17)
   785.18 INTERIOR LIGHTS; CURTAINS.
   (a) The interior of each licensed taxicab or automobile kept for hire shall
be illuminated from sundown to sunrise, so a countenance may be discerned at a
distance of fifteen feet at all times while such car is upon the streets within
the corporate limits of the City. At no time shall the curtains or shades of
such vehicle be drawn.
   (b) An automobile kept for hire shall not be enclosed by curtains unless
necessitated by the weather, and at no time shall the transparent openings or
windows in such curtains be covered. (1967 Code §§ 117.18, 117.19)
   758.19 DIRECT AND SAFE ROUTE.
   A person who has engaged a taxicab or an automobile for hire shall be
conveyed by the most direct and safe route to the place to which the person
wishes to go and not elsewhere.
(1967 Code §117.20)
   785.20 SIGNAL LIGHT.
   A signal light shall be installed on top of each taxicab in such position as
to be visible to motorists and pedestrians, such light to be burning at all
times when the taximeter in the taxicab is not in operation and not burning
when the taximeter is in operation. (1967 Code §117.21)
   785.21 CONDITION OF VEHICLES.
   All taxicabs, automobiles and motorcycles, kept for hire shall be kept and
maintained at all times in a safe operational condition, free from all defects
and in a presentable condition, and shall in such respects be at all times
subject to the approval of the Police Chief or his agent. (1967 Code §117.22)
   785.22 TAXICAB STANDS.
   (a) Markings. It shall be the duty of the Engineering Commissioner to
designate taxicab stands by a sign upon a permanent stanchion set at the curb.
The stanchion shall bear a legend indicating that it is a taxicab stand and
shall designate the number of vehicles which may occupy the stand.
   (b) Limitation on Use. In the case of stands upon which six or more taxicabs
may stand, not more than two vehicles of any one owner shall occupy the stand
at one time. In the case of stands limited to five taxicabs or less, not more
than one car of any one owner shall occupy the stand at one time.
   (c) Parking in Congested District. No owner or driver shall park any taxicab
nor shall the owner of any taxicab allow or permit the same to be parked, for
the purpose of soliciting business, at any place within the congested district,
other than upon established taxicab stands.
   (d) Method of Operation. No taxicab or automobile for hire standing at the
head of the line upon any taxicab stand shall refuse to carry any orderly
person applying for a car who agrees to pay the proper rate of fare. This shall
not prevent any person from selecting any car on the stand that he may desire,
whether the car be at the head of the line or not. As the car leaves the line
with passengers, those behind shall move up, and any taxicab or automobile for
hire seeking a space on a taxicab stand shall approach the same only from the
rear of the stand and shall stop as near as possible to the last car already in
the line.
   (e) Loitering. No person other than the driver, owner or representative of
the owner of a taxicab or automobile for hire occupying the public stands shall
loiter at or near such taxicab or automobile for hire. (1967 Code §§117.24 to
117.27, 117.29)
   785.23 FEES GENERALLY.
   (a) Payable in Advance. The fee for all licenses issued under provisions of
this chapter shall be payable in advance.
   (b) How Prorated. Fees for all licenses issued under provisions of this
chapter, having less than one year to run from date of issuance, shall be
computed on the quarter year basis, This computation shall be based on a
reduction of a quarter year amount for the time the license has to run before
its expiration.
   (c) Use and Disposition. Fees collected by the Mayor in carrying out the
provisions of Sections
785.23 to
785.27 shall be used by him to meet the expenses necessitated by a compliance
with the provisions of such sections. Such expenses shall be paid out of the
funds from the fees so collected. Any excess in the Mayor's hands shall be paid
into the General Fund.
(1967 Code §§117.29 to 117.31, 117.40)
   785.24 LICENSES GENERALLY.
   (a) Termination Date. The term of all licenses issued pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter shall terminate at 12:00 midnight on December 31 in
the year of issuance.
   (b) Transfer. Except as otherwise provided, all licenses issued under
provisions of this chapter shall be void if transferred.
   (c) Criminal Record of Applicant. No license provided for in this chapter
shall be granted to any person who has, within twelve months preceding the
application therefor, been convicted of a violation of liquor, gambling or
prostitution laws or ordinances.
(1967 Code §§117.32, 117.33, 117.39)
   785.25 OPERATOR'S LICENSE.
   (a)   Denial; Appeal. Whenever a person has applied for a license to operate
a taxicab or automobile kept for hire, or motorcycle for lease or rent, or as a
driver or chauffeur thereof, and has been refused a license by the Mayor, it
shall be the duty of the Mayor to notify the applicant in writing within five
days after his refusing the license, and to return therewith the advanced fee.
The person refused the license shall then have the right to appeal to a board
composed of the Mayor, the Police Chief and the Law Director. The board, after
full hearing, shall have the power to sustain or modify the Mayor's decision
and shall have the power to order the license granted and the action of this
board shall be final. In order to perfect this appeal, the applicant shall
serve written notice of his intention to appeal at the office of the Police
Chief within five days after receipt of notice from the Mayor that his
application has been rejected.
   (b)   Revocation.
      (1)   The Mayor may revoke any license covered by this chapter whenever
the person to whom the license has been granted has been convicted for
violation of any provision of this chapter, or whenever the Police Chief files
a recommendation with the Mayor that the license or permit shall be revoked.
      (2)   All licenses issued under provisions of this chapter shall be
subject to revocation by the Mayor for misconduct on the part of the licensee.
   (c)   Employment of Certain Persons Prohibited. Anyone licensed under
provisions of this chapter who permits a person whose taxicab license or
license for an automobile kept for hire, or leases or rents a motorcycle for
hire, or who operates the latter, or whose license to drive such motor vehicle
has been revoked by the proper authority, or who has been convicted of a
misdemeanor while in charge of and/or operation or control of a taxicab or
automobile or motorcycle kept for hire, rent or lease, to manage, drive,
control or in any manner direct such taxicab, or automobile or motorcycle kept
for rent, lease or hire, shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section
785.99 and shall further have his license revoked for a period of six months to
two years, as the court determines.
   (d)   Citizenship. No license to operate a taxicab, shall be granted to any
person, persons or association of persons not citizens of the United States.
   No license shall be granted to any corporation to engage in any of the
various trades, businesses and professions under the provisions of this
chapter, unless a majority of the stockholders of the corporation are citizens
of the United States. (1967 Code §§117.34 to 117.38)
   785.26 LICENSE FOR VEHICLE.
   (a)   Application. Each owner of taxicabs, automobiles and/or motorcycles
for rent, lease or hire shall apply to the Mayor for a license for each of the
aforesaid vehicles he owns. Application shall be made on forms provided by the
Mayor's office. The application forms shall provide space for the following
information:
      (1)   The full name of the person making application.
      (2)   If a firm or corporation, the members composing same, or the
officers thereof.
      (3)   Residence or place of business.
      (4)   The names of three persons to whom reference may be made as to the
character of the applicant(s).
      (5)   The make, style, seating capacity and State license number of each
machine or vehicle for which a license is requested.
         (1967 Code Sec. 117.41.)
   (b)   Additional License Fee. Each vehicle license application provided in
subsection (a) hereof shall be accompanied by a license fee of forty dollars
($40.00) per year per taxicab, effective January 1, 2005, and fifty dollars
($50.00) per year per taxicab, effective January 1, 2006, which shall be in
addition to the fee required to be paid on motor vehicles under State law.
(Ord. 04-167. Passed 7-21-04.)
   (c)   Fee To Be Paid in Advance. No owner, operator or driver shall use any
taxicab, automobile or motorcycle kept for rent, lease or hire upon City
streets without first paying the license fee required in subsection (b) hereof
and receiving a license therefor.
   (d)   Transfer of License. Upon the application of an owner of a taxicab or
automobile kept for hire to the Mayor, the latter may authorize the transfer of
a license issued for a particular taxicab or automobile kept for hire, to
another taxicab or automobile kept for hire, of the same owner. The transfer
shall be recorded on the record of licenses kept in the office, but it shall be
unlawful to make such transfer without first obtaining the consent of the
Mayor.
(1967 Code §§117.41, 117.43 to 117.45)
   785.27 DRIVER'S LICENSES.
   (a)   License Required. No person shall drive a taxicab, automobile and/or
motorcycle kept for rent, lease or hire without first securing a license to do
so from the Mayor.
   (b)   License Application. Application for a license by one who is to become
the operator, driver or chauffeur of a taxicab, automobile and/or motorcycle
kept for rent, lease or hire, shall be made in writing upon forms furnished by
the Mayor and filed in his office or another designated City office. Such
application shall contain the following information:
      (1)   Name of applicant.
      (2)   His permanent address.
      (3)   His age.
      (4)   The name(s) of his former employer(s) and present employer and the
length of time employed by each.
      (5)   The names of three persons who may be referred to as to the
applicant's character.
      (6)   A statement as to his arrest and convictions, if any, for violating
the laws of any state, or the ordinances of any city, and other information the
Mayor may require.
      (7)   The number of the State driver's license he holds, the date of
issue, and if currently in effect; and proof same is not cancelled or revoked.
   (c)   Grant or Refusal of License. If the Mayor is satisfied with the
applicant's qualifications and that the applicant is of good character and is a
suitable person to operate a taxicab or automobile kept for hire, he may grant
the application and issue a license. If the Mayor refuses to issue the license
he shall notify the applicant, returning the advanced fee with such notice. A
person refused a license shall have the right to appeal as provided in Section
785.25(a). (1967 Code Sec. 117.51.)
   (d)   License Fee.  Each application shall be accompanied by a fee of twenty
dollars ($20.00) per year, or any portion thereof, effective January 1, 2005.
(Ord. 04-170. Passed 7-21-04.)
   (e)   Badge. At the time of license issuance by the Mayor to the applicant
as a driver or chauffeur of a taxicab or automobile kept for hire, the Mayor
shall issue a badge to such driver or chauffeur. The size and design of the
badge shall be determined by the Mayor from time to time; on the badge shall be
inscribed or imprinted the words "Chauffeur No. _____", and the year of
issuing. Badges issued each year shall be numbered consecutively beginning with
No. 1, and the numbers shall correspond with the license number in each case.
   The badge shall be worn conspicuously by the driver upon the right sleeve of
his outer garment at all times while operating his taxicab or automobile kept
for hire, and the badge shall not be assigned or transferred to any other
person. Before the delivery of a badge to any person, however, there shall be
returned to the Mayor all badges theretofore issued such person, unless he, by
affidavit or by such other evidence as may be called for by the Mayor, shall
satisfy the Mayor that the badge previously issued to such person has been
lost, or for some other reason cannot be returned. Each badge holder shall,
upon discontinuing or abandoning the business licensed herein, return the badge
previously issued or delivered to him by the Mayor, or shall furnish to the
Mayor a good and satisfactory reason for his failure to return it.
(1967 Code §§117.50 to 117.54)
   785.28 MOTORCYCLE LICENSE.
   Any person, either as owner, agent, lessor or otherwise, who desires to
engage in the business of renting, leasing or keeping for hire, motorcycles in
the City, must secure a license to do so from the City as provided for herein.
Any person, seeking to rent, lease or hire a motorcycle must:
   (a)   Possess a State license to operate the motor vehicle; and
   (b)   Be eighteen years of age and capable, able and qualified to operate
such motor vehicle.
   It shall be the obligation and duty of the owner, agent or lessor of
motorcycles for hire to keep in the required records the age, name and
residence of the person hiring such motorcycle, the date, number and expiration
date of his driver's license. (1967 Code §117.54.1)
   785.29 TAXIMETERS.
   (a) Required. All taxicabs and automobiles for hire shall have a taximeter
affixed thereto.
   (b) Inspection. No person owning or operating any taxicab or automobile for
hire shall offer or let the same for hire or reward, anywhere within the City,
unless the taximeter affixed thereto has been examined, inspected and tested by
an officer of the City as provided in this section. If the taximeter after
examination, inspection and test does not properly and correctly register,
indicate or display the distance traveled, the time consumed, the amount of
extras used by the taxicab or automobile and the amount of fare determined and
charged therefor, no owner, operator or person in charge of such taxicab or
automobile for hire, shall use or permit the use of such vehicle until there is
affixed thereto a taximeter approved by the officer of the City as to its
ability to measure correctly. Nothing herein shall be construed as giving any
officer the right or authority to determine as to make, style or type used, so
long as the taximeter shall correctly measure and record distance traveled and
fare to be paid.
   (c) Exemptions. The requirements of subsections (a) and (b) hereof shall not
apply to motorcycles as herein defined, but shall apply to all other cars for
hire.
   (d) Meter to Register Properly and Correctly. No person shall permit to be
driven or shall drive a taxicab or automobile for hire or reward, within the
City, to which is attached a taximeter registering improperly or incorrectly.
   (e) Fare To Be Visible; Meter Lighted. Every taximeter shall be connected or
affixed to the taxicab or automobile for hire so that the amount of fare
determined and charged for its use is plainly visible from the inside of the
taxicab or automobile for hire to all passengers or occupants of the car.
During the period which, by law, motor vehicles are to be equipped with lights
on or about such taxicab or automobile kept for hire, there shall be a light
reflected upon the dial of the taximeter to enable passengers or occupants to
read the figures indicated thereon from the inside of the taxicab or automobile
for hire.
   (f) Duty of Sealer of Weights and Measures. It shall be the duty of the
Sealer of Weights and Measures to examine, inspect and seal all taximeters used
in the City at least once in every three months. In the event complaint is made
to the Sealer that any taximeter registers improperly or incorrectly, it shall
be his duty immediately to examine and inspect such taximeter.
   Every examination and inspection shall include the examination and
inspection of the taximeter affixed to the taxicab or automobile for hire and
of every wheel, tire, gear, shaft and other part of the mechanism which may
affect or control the operation of such taximeter. The usual standards of
measures and the tests shall be used therein by the Sealer. It shall be the
duty of the Sealer to seal all taximeters found correct and accurate and to
keep a record of the number of all taximeters and the date of the examination
and inspection thereof in the books of his office.
   (g) Examination and Inspection Fee. There shall be a seventy-five cent (75¢)
fee charged for examination and inspection of all taximeters, but no charge
shall be made for inspection made upon complaint unless the taximeters register
incorrectly or inaccurately.
   (h) Manipulating or Tampering With Taximeter. No person licensed under this
chapter shall manipulate or attempt to manipulate a taximeter, directly or
indirectly, in any manner or to attempt to cause it to measure or indicate
incorrectly.
   (i) Disposition of Fees. The money received by the City Sealer of Weights
and Measures for examining and inspecting taximeters shall be paid into the
General Fund.
(1967 Code §§ 117.55 to 117.63)
   785.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the fourth degree for the first offense and a misdemeanor of the third degree
for each subsequent offense. Each day's continued violation shall constitute a
separate offense.
CHAPTER 786
Clothing Donation Containers
 
 
786.01   Definitions.
786.02   Requirements.
786.03   Maintenance; enforcement.
786.04   Permit required; dates of issuance and expiration.
786.05   Application for the permit; contents; fees.
786.06   Permit number.
786.07   Relationship to other laws.
786.08   Unconstitutionality.
786.99   Penalty.
 
 
 
   786.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this Chapter, the following words are defined and shall
have the meaning ascribed to them as hereafter set forth:
   "Clothing Donation Containers" shall include, but not be limited to, any
box, building trailer or other receptacle that is intended for use as a
collection point for donated clothing or other household materials at times
when no employee or representative of the sponsoring company or organization is
present to accept donations.
(Ord. 14-145. Passed 6-4-14.)
 
   786.02 REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   The organization or company benefiting from the Clothing Donation
Container or the host site on whose property the Clothing Donation Container is
situated, must indicate the following information on the container or bin: name
of organization or company, address, and contact telephone number.
 
   (b)   All signage on each Clothing Donation Container shall be in compliance
with Chapter
1105, "Sign Regulations", as well as any other applicable Chapters and or
Sections of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Youngstown.
 
   (c)   Clothing Donation Containers shall be maintained in good condition and
appearance, with no structural damage, no holes in the container that would
allow leaks, no visible rust, and free of graffiti or advertising other than
the name of the host site or organization or company benefiting from the
Clothing Donation Container.
 
   (d)   The Clothing Donation Containers may only be used as collection
containers for clothing.
 
   (e)   The placement of Clothing Donation containers shall not impede traffic
nor visually impair any motor vehicle operation within a parking lot or from a
public street.
 
   (f)   Clothing Donation Containers may not be located on a vacant parcel or
on a parcel containing a vacant building.
 
   (g)   Clothing Donation Containers may not be located in a required building
setback, access easement, driveway, parking lane, fire lane or any area
prohibited by the City of Youngstown's Planning or Zoning Codes.
(Ord. 14-145. Passed 6-4-14.)
 
   786.03 MAINTENANCE; ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)   The organization or company benefiting from the Clothing Donation
Container will be held primarily responsible for the maintenance, upkeep, and
servicing of the container. However, in the event the organization fails to
adequately maintain and service the container, the business owner, or host
site, on whose property the Clothing Donation Container is placed, shall be
responsible.
 
   (b)   Failure to properly maintain the Clothing Donation Container may
result in enforcement under this Chapter or Section
521.08, Littering and Deposit of Garbage, Rubbish, Junk of the Codified
Ordinances of the City of Youngstown in the event of a violation of that
codified ordinance.
 
   (c)   Receipt of three (3) complaints that are verified by the City of
Youngstown Litter Control and Recycling Department, within a one year period,
regarding a specific Clothing Donation Container shall cause the declaration of
the Clothing Donation Container to be a public nuisance. The Clothing Donation
Container may be abated by the City at the owner's expense. Abatement may
include the removal of the Clothing Donation Container.
(Ord. 14-145. Passed 6-4-14.)
 
   786.04 PERMIT REQUIRED; DATES OF ISSUANCE AND EXPIRATION.
   (a)   Permit Required. A Clothing Donation Container permit shall be affixed
to every Container used by the permit holder for the collection and storage of
new or used clothing. A permit issued to a registrant shall be affixed to the
Container prior to placement. The permit shall be placed on the same side of
the Container as the chute used for the deposit of the clothing. Next to the
permit there shall be placed in clear lettering the name and telephone number
of the registrant. Upon the sale or transfer of a Container, a new permit
issued to the new owner shall be affixed to the Container prior to placing it
in service.
 
   (b)   A permit issued under this chapter shall be valid from the date of
issuance to the same date (Day and Month) of the following year and renewable
for one-year periods thereafter.
(Ord. 14-145. Passed 6-4-14.)
 
   786.05 APPLICATION FOR THE PERMIT; CONTENTS; FEES.
   (a)   The applicant shall complete a registration application in such form
as to be acceptable to the Engineering, Planning and Building Department. Such
application shall include but not be limited to the name, address and telephone
number of the person, business entity, corporation or organization applying for
the permit; the proposed location/address where the Container is to be placed;
the name and telephone number of the individual who will be placing the
Container; information as to the manner and schedule for which the Container is
to be emptied or removed and the destination of the clothing to be removed from
the Container. The applicant must submit a letter from the property owner
granting authority to the applicant to place the container on owner's property.
Said letter must be submitted at the time of filing the application.
 
   (b)   Fees. An application processing fee of Twenty -Five Dollars ($25.00)
shall be charged in advance for each one-year period the Container shall be in
place.
(Ord. 14-145. Passed 6-4-14.)
 
   786.06 PERMIT NUMBER.
   Each approved application shall be given a permit number issued by the
Engineering, Planning and Building Department that shall be affixed to the
Container as required by this chapter. (Ord. 14-145. Passed 6-4-14.)
 
   786.07 RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER LAWS.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to limit the City of Youngstown in
any way to use any or all other means available to remove the nuisance, or
summarily eliminate immediate hazards to the public health, safety or welfare
as granted in any ordinances of the City of Youngstown or the laws or
Constitution of the State of Ohio.
(Ord. 14-145. Passed 6-4-14.)
 
   786.08 UNCONSTITUTIONALITY.
   In the event any section or any part of this chapter is declared to be
unconstitutional, such declaration shall in no way affect the operation of any
other section or part thereof of this chapter, and the remainder of this
chapter shall remain in full force and effect.
(Ord. 14-145. Passed 6-4-14.)
 
   786.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree and is subject to prosecution and penalty of
not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty days, or both, for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. The
penalty provided herein shall be cumulative of other remedies provided by law.
(Ord. 14-145. Passed 6-4-14.)
 
CHAPTER 787
Theaters, Circuses and Other Shows
787.01   Classification; definitions.
787.02   License required.
787.03   License application.
787.04   License issuance; privileges.
787.05   License fees.
787.06   Bond for entertainments of second-class. (Repealed)
787.07   Certification of seating capacities.
787.08   Authorization for circus performances.
787.09   Indecent shows.
787.10   Trafficking in theatrical tickets.
787.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.48, 715.63, 3765.02
Contests or games at county fairs - see Ohio R.C. 1711.09, 1711.11
State licensing of portable amusement devices - see Ohio R.C.
1711.11(H); OAC 901-11-01
County license for public shows - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3765
Safety inspectors of portable amusement devices - see OAC 901-11-03
   787.01 CLASSIFICATION; DEFINITIONS.
   All theatricals, shows and amusements, field games and public exhibitions of
every kind, except those of a sexually oriented nature (Refer to Chapter 709,
Sexually Oriented Businesses), intended to amuse, instruct or entertain and to
which the public is required to pay a fee, are hereby divided into the
following classes. The theater, opera house, auditorium, hall, park, grounds,
tent or other enclosure, or place where it is intended to produce, offer or
present such entertainment is referred to by the general term "place". All
exhibitions and performances are designated as "entertainments".
   (a)   First Class. All entertainments of a theatrical, dramatic, operatic,
vaudeville or spectacular character and all entertainments by moving pictures.
   (b)   Second Class. All circuses and wild west shows.
   (c)   Third Class. All carnivals and street shows.
   (d)   Fourth Class. All exhibitions, entertainments or amusements not
included in any of the foregoing classes.
      (Ord. 04-291. Passed 11-17-04.))
   787.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall give, conduct, produce or offer for gain or profit any of
the entertainments as specified in the preceding section without first having
obtained a license as provided for in this chapter. (1967 Code §114.02)
   787.03 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Any person desiring to produce, operate or offer for gain or profit, any of
the classes of entertainment as described in Section
787.01 at any place within the City shall make application in writing for such
license to the Mayor, conforming to the general provisions of ordinances
relating to license applications and shall set forth therein a description of
the place where it is proposed to offer such entertainment and a description of
the kind and class of such entertainment; and if such place has a seating
capacity, listing the capacity. (1967 Code §114.03)
   787.04 LICENSE ISSUANCE; PRIVILEGES.
   If upon investigation, as required by general City ordinances, it is found
that the State laws, and the City ordinances relating to the health, sanitation
and safety of such place have been complied with, then a license shall be
issued upon payment of the license fee. The license shall entitle the licensee
to conduct, produce, operate or offer the class of entertainment specified in
the license at the place and for the time designated in the application. (1967
Code §114.04)
   787.05 LICENSE FEES.
   No license to produce, conduct, operate or offer entertainment, as specified
in the classes enumerated in Section
787.01 shall be granted until the applicant pays in advance a license fee in
accordance with the following schedule:
   (a)   First Class. For houses having a seating capacity of 1,000 or more,
one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per year.
      (1)   For drive-in theaters having accommodations for 500 or more cars,
one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per year.
      (2)   For houses having a seating capacity of not less than 600 and not
more than 1,000, one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year.
      (3)   For houses having a seating capacity of 400 and not more than 600
the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per year.
      (4)   For houses having less than 400 seating capacity, the sum of fifty
dollars ($50.00) per year.
      (5)   Private theatricals and entertainments of the first class, given
for charity may be produced in unlicensed places.
      (6)   Concerts and musical entertainments consisting of vocal and/or
instrumental music may be produced in unlicensed halls and the fee for such
performances, if the seating capacity is over 350, shall be five dollars
($5.00) for each day on which such performance is given.
   (b)   Second Class. Seating capacity, 2,000 or less, seventy-five dollars
($75.00) for the first day and twenty dollars ($20.00) for each additional day;
seating capacity, over 2,000, two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the first day
and seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for each additional day.
   (c)   Third Class. The fee shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) per day.
   (d)   Fourth Class. The fee shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per year.
   However, this chapter shall not extend to any exhibition by the pupils of
any private or public school, or to any musical entertainment given by the
members and for the benefit of any musical society, or to any exhibition of
painting, engraving, sculpturing or fine art executed by a resident of the
City, or to any concert or musical entertainment, fair, festival or lecture for
the benefit of any benevolent group. (Ord. 88-507. Passed 7-22-88.)
   787.06 BOND FOR ENTERTAINMENTS OF SECOND CLASS. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
787.06 was repealed by Ordinance 15-339.
   787.07 CERTIFICATION OF SEATING CAPACITIES.
   Any person applying for a license, the fee for which is regulated by seating
capacity, shall certify in writing to the Mayor the seating capacity of the
entertainment for which a license is desired.
   No person shall make any false statement in the certificate. (1967 Code
§114.07)
   787.08 AUTHORIZATION FOR CIRCUS PERFORMANCES.
   The Mayor is authorized, at his discretion, to issue a license and permit to
circuses for one day and evening performance on property in the City and to
waive compliance with any existing zoning or building ordinances to permit the
circus exhibition. (1967 Code §114.08)
   787.09 INDECENT SHOWS.
   No person shall act, exhibit, show or perform or be in any manner concerned
in the acting, exhibiting or performance of an indecent or blasphemous play,
farce, operetta, public exhibition, show or entertainment. (1967 Code §114.09)
   787.10 TRAFFICKING IN THEATRICAL TICKETS.
   No person shall engage in the business of trafficking in theatrical tickets
or other tickets of license amusements unless acting as agent of those issuing
same, but public school entertainments, lecture courses and lectures on
historic, literary or scientific subjects shall not come within the provisions
of this section. (1967 Code §114.12)
   787.99 PENALTY.
   (a) Whoever fails to secure a license for entertainments as specified in
Section
787.01, for the entertainments existing on or before February 1 of each year,
and fails to secure such license on or before February 15 of each year, or
fails in all other cases to secure a license within fifteen days of the opening
or beginning of such entertainment shall be fined fifty percent (50%) of the
regular license fee, in addition to the regular license fee which shall be
charged and collected.
   (b) Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which no other
penalty is provided is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
   (c) Whoever makes false statement in a seating capacity certificate as
provided for in Section
787.07 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree.
   In addition to the penalty, the Mayor may revoke the license of the person
certifying such false statement.
CHAPTER 789
Prisoner Accommodation Fee
789.01    Fee.
   789.01 FEE.
   Any private institution, corporation or business which, after December 1,
2009, houses prisoners or inmates serving a jail or prison sentence as a result
of a conviction or convictions of crimes shall be required to pay a fee of
$1.00 per day to the City of Youngstown, Ohio for each day each prisoner or
inmate meeting said description is housed at a facility in Youngstown, Ohio.
Payment shall be made on a monthly basis to the City of Youngstown Finance
Department. It shall be paid no later than the fifteenth (15th) day of the
month subsequent to the month in which the fees are incurred. (Ord. 09-323.
Passed 11-6-09.)

CHAPTER 905
General Provisions
905.01   Transportating materials over paved streets.
905.02   Street names; interference with sign placement; defacement of signs.
905.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
                  Special assessments - see CHTR. §
95 et seq.
                 Loads dropping or leaking - see TRAF.
339.08
                  Criminal mischief - see GEN. OFF.
541.04
   905.01 TRANSPORTING MATERIALS OVER PAVED STREETS.
   No contractor or builder shall transport earth, construction equipment or
materials incidental to construction, over any paved street of the City without
first making a cash deposit with the Engineering Commissioner as hereinafter
provided.
   Before any contractor or builder transports earth, construction equipment or
materials incidental to construction, over any paved street, he shall deposit
with the Commissioner of Engineering, cash, in an amount not exceeding 1/10th
of one percent (.10%) of the total amount of the contract price, but in no
event shall the deposit be less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more
than five thousand dollars ($5,000), as a guarantee that the contractor or
builders will clean and/or repair any damage which may occur to City streets
because of the hauling of such earth, construction equipment or materials
incidental to construction. In each case the contractor or builder fails to
clean or repair the street to the satisfaction of the Engineering Commissioner
or his duly designated assistant, then the City, by and through its Engineering
Commissioner, shall repair and clean the street and deduct the cost of such
work from the moneys so deposited as herein required and return the balance
remaining, if any, to the contractor or builder making the deposit. (1967 Code
§95.24)
   905.02 STREET NAMES; INTERFERENCE WITH SIGN PLACEMENT; DEFACEMENT OF SIGNS.
   (a)   The names of all streets, avenues, squares, parks, lanes and alleys in
the City shall be legibly marked at the corners thereof, and shall be done by
and at the expense of the City.
   (b)   No person shall willfully obstruct or interfere with any person
authorized to place the names of streets, avenues, squares, parks, lanes and
alleys at corners thereof or tear down, remove or deface the same. (1967 Code
§95.33, 95.34)
   905.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the third degree.

909.09   Disposition of excavated materials.
909.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Liability for damage - see Ohio R.C. 723.49 et seq.
Barricades and warning lights - see GEN. OFF.
521.03
Sewer connections - see S.U. & P.S.
931.04
   909.01 RIGHT OF WAY EXCAVATION PERMIT REQUIRED.
   A right of way excavation permit issued by the Engineering Commissioner
shall be required of all firms, corporations, companies or individuals prior to
any excavation being performed in a street, alley or other public right of way
in the City, whether in the paved portion of the right of way or not, for the
purpose of maintaining, replacing, constructing, repair or rehabilitation of
all underground lines, conduits, mains, structures, manholes, hand holes, lamp
holes or other major subsurface installations, except work which is being done
and paid for as a part of a construction contract with the City.
   All street opening permits shall be obtained at least forty-eight hours
prior to the beginning of the work unless work is of an emergency nature where
special permission may be given by the Engineering Commissioner. Street opening
permits shall be valid for the time limit shown on the permit. If the entity
performing the right of way excavation fails to complete satisfactory
restoration of the area within 30 days of the expiration of the right of way
excavation permit they will be subject to a fifty dollars ($50.00) per day
penalty.
(Ord. 10-333. Passed 10-20-10.)
   909.02 PERMIT FEES.
   Fees for right of way excavation permits shall be paid, upon application, to
the City Finance Director in accordance with the following schedule:
 
                                          Per Opening
(a)    Limited Access Expressways   $500.00
(b)    Major Streets                   $100.00
(c)    Secondary Major Streets         $50.00
(d)    Central Business District Street$100.00
(e)    Residential Streets and All Othe$25.00
   Limited access expressways, major streets and secondary major streets shall
be as outlined in the "Street Classification Plan for the City of Youngstown"
available from the Engineering Division. Central Business District streets
shall be those streets bounded by Rayen Avenue, Front Street, Belmont Avenue
and Andrew Avenue, including these boundary streets.
(Ord. 10-333. Passed 10-20-10.)
   909.03 LONG LINE PERMIT; FEES.
   A long line permit shall be issued by the Engineering Commissioner to cover
work considered to be of a continuous nature over a relatively long length of
right of way, specifically in the case of the installation of new lines, piping
or conduits or the replacement of lines, piping or conduits where the length of
the work exceeds 50 linear feet. Fees for a long line permit shall be paid,
upon application, to the City Finance Director in accordance with the following
schedule:
 
 
                                          Long Line Permit Fees Per Opening
(a)    Limited Access Expressways      $1,000.00*
(b)    Major Streets                   $200.00*
(c)    Secondary Major Streets         $100.00*
(d)    Central Business District Street$200.00*
(e)    Residential Streets and All Othe$50.00*
*   Plus $10.00 for every 100 foot section after the initial 50 feet covered by
the base permit fee.
   Inspection charges shall be due and payable upon invoice by the Engineering
Commissioner and shall be kept current. Failure to maintain a current account
will be just cause for the refusal of all future permits of any type. Detailed
plans governing long line work shall be submitted at least ten days prior to
permit application for approval by the Engineering Commissioner. No permit
governing this work will be issued prior to approval of detailed plans. Plan
approval includes location of work, methods of construction, types of
materials, pedestrian and vehicular traffic controls, types of pavement
restoration, lawn restoration, time limits and any other requirement deemed
necessary to insure the public health, safety and welfare.
(Ord. 10-333. Passed 10-20-10.)
   909.04 RESTORATION OF OPENINGS; FEES.
   (a)    Restoration of all openings in pavement areas shall be performed by
the applicant. All restoration, whether in paved areas or unpaved areas, and
whether they are in street-opening-permit areas or long line permit areas,
shall be in accordance with the standard drawings, on file with the Engineering
Commissioner, deemed applicable to the condition. The City shall reserve the
right to repair or replace any restored area which is not deemed acceptable by
the Engineering Commissioner and assess all costs including fifteen percent
(15%) for handling to the applicant.
   (b)    When restorations are made by the City, the applicant shall be
assessed the actual cost of the restoration, including all labor, material and
equipment costs including a handling charge of fifteen percent (15%). Payment
for restoration charges shall be kept current or existing or future permits may
be revoked or denied. In the event that a restoration being performed by the
applicant is not proceeding satisfactorily, the Engineering Commissioner may
order the work performed by City forces with charges assessed as described in
this section. A penalty of five dollars ($5.00) a day shall be assessed for
each day beyond the permitted amount that street openings are not available for
restoration by the Street Department.
(Ord. 10-333. Passed 10-20-10.)
   909.05 OPENINGS IN NEW PAVEMENTS.
   New pavements shall be considered those pavements which have been newly
constructed in part, or in total or newly resurfaced in part, or in total in
the five-year period prior to the permit application date.
   Permit fees for openings in new pavements shall be five times the normal fee
as outlined in Section
909.02, and permits in new pavements shall be issued only with written approval
of the Engineering Commissioner. The increase in fee shall not apply to
inspection charges or restoration charges.
   In the case of long line permits in new pavements, the fee shall be five
times the normal fee as outlined in Section
 909.03, and permits shall be issued only after approval of detailed plans and
with written approval of the Engineering Commissioner. In the event of a long
line street opening for a roadway which had been newly constructed in part, or
in total or newly resurfaced in part, or in total in the three-year period
prior to the permit application date, the Engineering Commissioner reserves the
right to require full-width restoration and paving of the affected area of
roadway at the applicant’s expense.
(Ord. 10-333. Passed 10-20-10.)
   909.06 FIELD INSPECTION.
   For the purpose of the field supervision and inspection of all work governed
by the issuance of the above described permits, the position of Utilities
Inspector in the Department of Public Works shall be created, the salary for
which shall be supported by the permit fees collected.
(Ord. 10-333. Passed 10-20-10.)
   909.07 EMERGENCY OPENINGS.
   In the event of an emergency, or where the public health, safety and welfare
are involved, street openings may be made immediately by the proper authority
provided, however, that immediate notification be given to the Engineering
Commissioner, or one of his representatives. The intent of this section is the
waiver of prior application and approvals by the Engineering Commissioner. In
no case is it intended that permit fees, restoration fees or inspection fees be
waived. These are computed and levied as previously described in the above
various sections.
(Ord. 10-333. Passed 10-20-10.)
   909.08 LIABILITY.
   All firms, corporations, companies or individuals seeking the issuance of a
permit for performance of any of the services or work above set out shall, at
the time before a permit is issued, furnish a liability insurance rider or
policy of liability insurance, against personal liability and/ or property
damage, indemnifying the City against all loss as a result of their performance
under such permit in sums of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) to three
hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) for personal injury and fifty thousand
dollars ($50,000) to one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) for property
damage.
(Ord. 10-333. Passed 10-20-10.)
   909.09 DISPOSITION OF EXCAVATED MATERIALS.
   (a)    All earth, cinder, ashes, stone, brick or other material excavated
while street improvements are being made shall, if possible, be replaced
therein; if not possible, it shall be removed from the streets by the person
making the improvement or doing the work, immediately upon the completion of
the same.
   (b)    Stockpiling and storing of dirt or excavated material from building
excavations, street or sewer excavations, on residentially zoned areas other
than on the prime construction site and immediate adjacent areas is prohibited.
The area surrounding the prime construction site and adjacent sidewalks and
streets shall be kept clean of all dirt and material until the completion of
the project and the restoration of the area.
(Ord. 10-333. Passed 10-20-10.)
   909.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which no other penalty is
provided is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. Whoever violates
Section
909.09(b) is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree.
(Ord. 10-333. Passed 10-20-10.)
CHAPTER 911
Construction and Maintenance Standards
911.01   Permit required; standards to be followed; supervision.
911.02   Preparation and revision of specifications and standards.
911.03   Prerequisites to approval of subdivisions.
911.04   Annexed territory.
911.05   Rules and regulations for of plans, etc.
911.06   Cost of supervision and inspection.
911.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Surface treatment - see Ohio R.C. 723.23, 723.31
Changing established grade - see Ohio R.C. 727.07
Sidewalk specifications - see S.U. & P.S.
913.01 et seq.
   911.01 PERMIT REQUIRED; STANDARDS TO BE FOLLOWED; SUPERVISION.
   No sidewalk or street paving or grading shall be constructed in the City by
any person, except if done in pursuance of a permit to be secured from the
Department of Public Works; in accordance with the specifications and standards
as prepared by the Department; and under the supervision, inspection and
direction of the Department. (1967 Code §95.46)
   911.02 PREPARATION AND REVISION OF SPECIFICATIONS AND STANDARDS.
   The Department of Public Works shall prepare, and may revise from time to
time, specifications and standards for the construction, maintenance and repair
of sidewalks, streets and street grading and paving; in no case shall the
required thickness for sidewalks be less than five inches of concrete, except
those portions of sidewalks to be used for driveway purposes which shall be
required to have a thickness of at least six inches of concrete, containing not
less than 6.95 sacks of cement per cubic yard, on a sub-base of selected
material of not less than four inches in thickness. (1967 Code §95.47)
   911.03 PREREQUISITES TO APPROVAL OF SUBDIVISIONS.
   As to all construction and repairs of streets, sidewalks and street grading
and paving, no plat or subdivision of platted land, either within the Municipal
limits or within three miles of the limits, shall be approved for platting and
record by the Planning Commission unless a certificate of the Department of
Public Works is submitted along with the plat, which certificate shall certify
that the plans, profiles and specifications of the streets, sidewalks and
street grading and paving in the plats have been inspected and approved and a
copy of the plans, profiles and specifications placed on file by the Department
of Public Works. (1967 Code §95.48)
   911.04 ANNEXED TERRITORY.
   No territory lying outside of, but within three miles of the Municipal
limits, as the limits exist at present, or as the same may be altered from
time, shall be annexed to the City until all construction or repairs of all
sidewalks, street or street grading and paving complies with the standards and
specifications of the City. (1967 Code §95.49)
   911.05 RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR SUBMISSION OF PLANS, ETC.
   The Department of Public Works shall make such rules and regulations
requiring the submission of plans and specifications as may be necessary and
proper. (1967 Code §95.50)
   911.06 COST OF SUPERVISION AND INSPECTION.
   In addition to the permit provided for in Section
911.01 the Department of Public Works shall charge the cost of the supervision
and inspection of the construction or repairs of any such sidewalk, street or
street grading and paving, to the owner of the abutting property, such charge
to be computed on the basis of the current cost of inspection in the Department
of Engineering. (1967 Code §95.51)
   911.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the third degree.
